options: It should be placed on a front passenger seat only.
It should be placed on the floor.
It should be left unsecured.
It should be fitted in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions.
allQuestions.explanation: It is recommended to fit the child seat correctly, according to the manufacturer's instructions, it is safer to fit the seat in the back seat of the car and to buy a child car seat only from a retailer who will check that it fits both the car and the child.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do when they want to use a mobile phone?
options: Reduce speed, show caution, and be alert for other road users.
Allow a wider gap to open up with the vehicle in front and continue at normal speed.
Keep the conversation short.
Pull in and stop in a safe place.
allQuestions.explanation: It is illegal to use or handle a mobile phone while driving. Driving requires all of your attention, all of the time, so you should never use or handle a mobile phone while driving. If you want to use a mobile phone, the only safe thing to do is to find a safe  place to stop.

allQuestions.question: Why might it be dangerous to drive on a poorly-lit street?
options: Traffic lights will not be working.
Drivers can only see the traffic coming against them.
Drivers can only see the traffic in front of them.
It may be difficult to make out poorly lit vehicles in the dark areas.
allQuestions.explanation: When you are driving along a poorly-lit street, you should take extra care and be prepared to react to hazards such as unlit parked vehicles.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do if dazzled by the lights of an oncoming vehicle?
options: Flash the oncoming vehicle and move to the left.
Look to the left-hand edge (nearside) of the roadway and slow down if necessary.
Accelerate to get out of range of light as quickly as possible.
allQuestions.explanation: If you are dazzled by the lights of oncoming traffic, turn your eyes to the left edge (nearside) of the road. If necessary, stop and allow your eyes to recover before driving on.

allQuestions.question: When should signals (for example, with indicators) be given to other road users?
options: Only when it is necessary to warn following traffic.
Clearly and in good time to let other road users know what you intend to do.
When turning, except where road markings indicate your direction.
allQuestions.explanation: Giving signals is a way of telling other road users what you intend to do. So, you should signal properly before moving off, turning right or left, changing lanes, overtaking, slowing down or stopping. Signal clearly and in good time, and keep in mind that giving a signal does not give you the right of way.

allQuestions.question: Is a driver permitted to pick up or set down a passenger on a motorway?
options: It is only permitted within 200 metres of a slip-road.
It is not permitted, except during daylight hours.
A driver is never permitted to pick up or set down passengers on a motorway.
It is permitted provided that the driver stops on the hard-shoulder.
allQuestions.explanation: Motorways are designed so that traffic can move faster and more freely. It is illegal and dangerous to stop a vehicle on any part of a motorway except in an emergency or when signalled to do so by a Garda.

allQuestions.question: An approaching driver notices that the boy on the children's bicycle has said goodbye to his friend. What is the correct action for the driver to take?
options: Stop the car until the boy has moved off.
Proceed as the boy is on the footpath.
Slow down and beckon the boy to cross the road.
Be prepared for the boy setting off at any moment.
allQuestions.explanation: Because it is difficult to predict children's behaviour, you should always be prepared to react to a change in the traffic situation or to stop.

allQuestions.question: What must a driver be prepared for in this situation?
options: A child could turn back to collect the ball from the roadway.
The oncoming vehicle may swerve in your direction.
The ball may burst after you have passed.
The ball could damage your vehicle.
allQuestions.explanation: Because it is difficult to predict children's behaviour, you should always be prepared to react to a change in the traffic situation and be prepared to stop.

allQuestions.question: When approaching the pedestrian crossing, what should the driver do in this situation?
options: Slow down in good time and be prepared to stop.
Maintain speed, because the pedestrians have not stepped on to the crossing.
Continue to drive on fast because the pedestrians have to wait.
allQuestions.explanation: When there are pedestrians at or near a Zebra crossing, you should slow down on approach and be prepared to stop to allow the pedestrians to cross safely.

allQuestions.question: What should the driver do if there are children playing at the edge of the roadway?
options: Accelerate and move to the right-hand side of the road to avoid the children.
Give a warning signal and drive past at the same speed.
Reduce speed, drive cautiously and remain ready to brake.
allQuestions.explanation: Because it is difficult to predict children's behaviour, you should always be prepared to react to a change in the traffic situation and be prepared to stop.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver be conscious of in this situation?
options: The bus may start to reverse.
Traffic emerging from the street on the left.
People crossing the street at the rear of the bus.
The bus driver will always signal before moving off.
allQuestions.explanation: You should always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to the changing traffic situation. In particular, you should be aware that pedestrians might emerge at the rear of the bus. In this situation you should also look out for pedestrians making their way towards the waiting bus.

allQuestions.question: The silver car is overtaking the parked red car, what should the driver do in this situation?
options: The driver should move closer to the red car.
The driver should drive on at the same speed.
The driver should drive on if he does not hit the ball.
Reduce speed considerably and be ready to stop.
allQuestions.explanation: You should read the road and be extra careful while driving through an area where children might be playing. When a ball bounces out on the road you should expect that a child might follow to retrieve the ball.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver be aware of in this situation?
options: The pedestrian may leave the traffic island without paying attention.
There is no danger as the tram is on rails.
The pedestrian always has the right of way to cross in front of traffic.
The tram may move away without warning.
allQuestions.explanation: You should read the road ahead and expect extra pedestrian activity when the tram is at the stop.

allQuestions.question: The driver is following these two vehicles and wishes to overtake - what must the driver consider before overtaking here?
options: The driver should overtake both vehicles together.
The driver of the silver car may decide to turn right.
The roadway markings forbid overtaking here.
The driver's field of view is not good enough to allow safe overtaking.
allQuestions.explanation: You should always make sure that the road ahead is clear so that there is enough distance to allow you to overtake and get back to the correct side of the road without forcing any other road user to alter speed or course. In this case, the brow of the hill is too close to allow a driver to overtake safely.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver be aware of when approaching a vehicle which is attempting to park?
options: That the vehicle being parked may move out without warning.
The driver may have to stop and assist the driver parking the vehicle.
The vehicle may be parking at an area designated for loading.
That there may be a driveway at the point where the vehicle is parking.
allQuestions.explanation: When you approach a vehicle that is being parked on the roadway, you should be aware that its driver will probably be concentrating on parking the vehicle and may not be aware of moving out into the road to correct its position.

allQuestions.question: What should the driver be most conscious of in this situation?
options: The pedestrian may suddenly cross the road in front of the vehicle.
No vehicles should be parked on the left-hand side of the road.
The pedestrian always has right of way to cross the road.
One of the parked vehicles may reverse into the driver's path.
allQuestions.explanation: It is often difficult to predict other road users behaviour. Where there are parked vehicles on both sides of the road you should approach with caution, and be prepared to react to a change in the traffic situation and to stop.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do when travelling behind this vehicle?
options: Pass the vehicle slowly by mounting the kerb on the left.
Reduce speed and prepare to stop if necessary.
Overtake the vehicle in front.
Drive as close as possible to the vehicle.
allQuestions.explanation: You should always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to the changing traffic situation as you approach junctions.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver be aware of in this situation?
options: There may be a car hidden from view in front of the bus.
The bus may be parked at a terminus.
Only buses may use this road.
allQuestions.explanation: On approach to an area with a restricted view you should be extra careful and be prepared to react to a change in the traffic situation.

allQuestions.question: When driving on this one-way street with vehicles parked on both sides, what should a driver be prepared for?
options: Oncoming traffic as the driver overtakes the truck.
The truck may be a left-hand drive vehicle.
A vehicle door may open on either side of the street.
allQuestions.explanation: When driving on a one-way street, you should be extra careful and should be prepared to react to a change in the traffic situation.

allQuestions.question: What should the car driver be aware of in this situation?
options: The road ahead becomes a dual carriageway.
Road marking is taking place ahead.
Following traffic may cut the corner.
Slowing down and being prepared to react.
allQuestions.explanation: When you are approaching a bend or corner with a restricted view you should slow down if necessary and be prepared to react to any changes in the traffic situation.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver be aware of when driving at night along a shopping street with many different light sources?
options: It is easier to see pedestrians because of the bright lights.
Parking spaces may be difficult to notice.
Traffic lights may be difficult to distinguish from the other bright lights.
Other vehicles do not need to use their head lights.
allQuestions.explanation: When driving at night in an area where there is a variety of light sources, you need to be extra careful, as potential hazards might be more difficult to see.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver be most aware of in this situation?
options: A car might appear unexpectedly at the brow of the hill.
Children may unexpectedly run out from between parked cars.
One of the parked vehicles may reverse into the driver's path.
Parking opposite double yellow lines is prohibited.
allQuestions.explanation: When driving in a residential area you need to take account of the danger you might pose to children playing. You should always observe warning signs relating to children and drive accordingly.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do in this situation?
options: Reduce speed and be prepared to stop as other children could follow.
Sound the horn as a warning and proceed.
Continue ahead while indicating to overtake parked car.
allQuestions.explanation: Drivers should always be aware of other road users especially children, who can be unpredictable and show no road sense. Drivers should slow down and take extra care in areas where there are children about - for example, near schools, playgrounds and in residential areas.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver be aware of in this situation?
options: A minor road to the right ahead.
A dangerous right-hand bend ahead.
A sharp dip in the road ahead.
A minor road to the left ahead.
allQuestions.explanation: You should always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to changing traffic situations - in this case paying attention to the warning sign clearly indicating a right-hand bend ahead.

allQuestions.question: What should the driver do when there is a sharp dip in the road ahead?
options: Pull in, stop and switch on hazard warning lights.
Increase speed and make progress through the dip.
Reduce speed, keep to the left and be alert for hazards ahead.
Move to the centre of the road in order to avoid any vehicles that might be parked on the left.
allQuestions.explanation: As you approach a sharp dip in the road, you should be aware that there might be hidden dangers ahead. For example, there might be pedestrians, cyclists or other approaching traffic, or the road could be flooded in the dip. You should always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to changing traffic situations - you might need to reduce your speed and drive with extra care.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do if they see a red warning triangle on the road?
options: The driver should maintain speed, carry on and avoid the triangle.
The driver should slow down and expect a hazard up ahead.
The driver should remove the triangle as it is causing an obstruction on the road.
The driver should stop and await instructions.
allQuestions.explanation: Warning triangles are used to alert approaching traffic that there is a vehicle breakdown or collision ahead. When you come across a warning triangle, you should slow down and be prepared to stop if necessary. Do not allow yourself to be distracted by the incident.

allQuestions.question: The driver is approaching traffic lights that they know have been green for some time. What should the driver do?
options: The driver should maintain speed until the light changes to amber.
The driver should be aware that the lights may change and accelerate to clear the lights before they do.
The driver should be aware that the lights may change before they reach them and be prepared to stop.
The driver should stop as the lights are about to change to red.
allQuestions.explanation: You should always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to changing traffic situations. Where traffic lights have been green for some time, you should be prepared to stop, as the lights are probably about to change to amber.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do when approaching a junction normally controlled by traffic lights and the traffic lights are not lighting?
options: Proceed smartly through the junction to avoid delay.
Switch on headlights, move to centre of the junction and proceed as quickly as possible.
Stop at the junction and give way to traffic on the left.
Treat it as an unmarked junction and proceed cautiously while watching out for other traffic.
allQuestions.explanation: You should always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to changing traffic situations. If the traffic lights are not working, you should approach the junction with extra care, and you should proceed only if it is safe to do so.

allQuestions.question: What should the driver do if there are cattle on the road ahead?
options: The driver should sound the horn to try to get the cattle to move aside.
The driver should reduce speed and pass them with care.
The driver should switch on the headlights and try to pass as quickly as possible.
The driver should sound the horn, switch on headlights, reduce speed and pass with care.
allQuestions.explanation: You should always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to changing traffic situations. If you meet cattle or other animals on the road, you should slow down and be prepared to stop. Don't use the horn or do anything that might frighten the animals. You must stop if directed to do so by the person in charge of animals.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do if they see horse riders on the road ahead?
options: The driver should increase speed and allow extra clearance.
The driver should reduce speed, allow extra clearance and pass with care.
The driver should reduce speed and sound the horn.
The driver should turn on hazard warning lights and continue at normal speed.
allQuestions.explanation: You should always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to changing traffic situations. If you meet horses or other animals on the road, you should slow down and be prepared to stop. Don't use the horn or do anything that might frighten the animals. You must stop if directed to do so by the person in charge of animals.

allQuestions.question: What should drivers be aware of if they meet horses with riders on the road?
options: Drivers should be aware that loud noises from their vehicle will not frighten the horses.
Drivers should be aware that horse riders are obliged to dismount and control their horses while traffic is passing.
Drivers should be aware that loud noises from their vehicle may frighten the horses and cause them to bolt.
Drivers should be aware that all horse riders are experienced at handling horses.
allQuestions.explanation: You must know your responsibilities towards animal traffic on the road. Horses are easily startled and any sudden noises or activity could cause them to bolt.

allQuestions.question: What should the driver do when approaching a humpbacked hill?
options: The driver should reduce speed, keep to the left and be alert for hazards ahead.
The driver should maintain normal speed and road position.
The driver should increase speed and make progress over the humpbacked hill.
The driver should move to the centre in order to avoid vehicles that may be parked on the left.
allQuestions.explanation: As you approach a humpbacked bridge or hill, you should be aware that there might be hidden dangers ahead - for example, overtaking traffic coming towards you. You should always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to changing traffic situations such as this.

allQuestions.question: What danger can arise during daylight when a driver enters an area that is heavily shaded by overhanging trees?
options: Visibility could suddenly be reduced.
The vehicle engine could suddenly run cold.
The tyre pressure could be reduced.
The vehicle's windscreen could fog up.
allQuestions.explanation: When you enter a heavily shaded area after driving in bright sunlight, it might take a while for your eyes to adjust to the change, and you might not see a hazard immediately ahead.

allQuestions.question: How does giving a late signal affect other road users?
options: They are not affected.
It only affects other road users at traffic lights.
It only affects other road users at roundabouts.
They may not have been given enough time to react.
allQuestions.explanation: Giving signals is a way of telling other road users what you intend to do. So, you should signal properly before moving off, turning right or left, changing lanes, overtaking, slowing down or stopping. Signal clearly and in good time, and keep in mind that giving a signal does not give you the right of way. Late signals may confuse other road users.

allQuestions.question: When a driver is at a junction where visibility is extremely limited, what should the driver do?
options: Sound the horn and quickly proceed.
Move the vehicle out onto the road to enable other drivers to see you.
Move out with extreme care, watching carefully to the left and right.
allQuestions.explanation: Where your view is obstructed at a junction, you should move carefully into a position where you can see, but without interfering with other road users. You should then assess the situation before you continue.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do when approaching traffic lights stuck on red?
options: Indicate and increase speed.
Stop and proceed with great caution.
Sound the horn and proceed ahead.
Check that there are no oncoming vehicles and increase speed.
allQuestions.explanation: On approach to traffic lights that are stuck on red, a driver should stop and proceed with caution when the way is clear.

allQuestions.question: What should a rider be aware of when crossing road markings such as lines or arrows?
options: Steering is improved.
Tyre grip is reduced.
Tyre grip is not affected.
allQuestions.explanation: Riding on just 2 wheels, riders need to be on the constant lookout for irregularities and other problems with the road surface. This can include all road markings.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do when approaching roadworks warning signs?
options: Maintain speed until signalled to slow down by a flagman.
Increase speed and move to the centre of the road.
Reduce speed and be prepared to stop for works vehicles or a flagman.
allQuestions.explanation: A driver should always approach roadworks with caution and reduce speed as there are many possible hazards to deal with - including road workers, works vehicles, uneven road surfaces and temporary traffic controls.

allQuestions.question: If a driver suspects that their vehicle indicators have not been seen, what should the driver do?
options: The driver's position on the road is enough of a signal.
It is unnecessary to give signals provided observation is taken.
Use a clear, decisive hand signal as well.
allQuestions.explanation: If the driver is concerned that for whatever reason the indicators are not giving an adequate signal, they should use clear decisive hand signals as well to advise other road users of their intention.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do to avoid the need for harsh braking?
options: Drive with one foot resting on the clutch pedal.
Look ahead and be prepared for what others may do.
Drive with cruise control engaged.
Drive with one foot resting on the brake pedal.
allQuestions.explanation: You should know what speed you're travelling at and you should always drive at a speed that is appropriate to the conditions you are driving in, and you should be able to stop smoothly and safely within the distance you can see to be clear ahead.

allQuestions.question: When driving along and wishing to use a hand-held mobile phone, what should a driver do?
options: Steer with one hand.
Stop at a safe location before using the phone.
Secure the phone between head and shoulders while steering with both hands.
Move the phone as needed and keep the call to just a few minutes.
allQuestions.explanation: It is an offence and very unsafe to use a hand-held mobile phone while driving a vehicle or riding a motorbike as it prevents you from concentrating fully on your driving. While using a hands-free phone kit is not illegal, in some circumstances it could be a dangerous distraction, and you could be prosecuted for dangerous driving, careless driving or driving without due care and attention. allQuestions.question: Why is tailgating (driving too close behind the vehicle in front) dangerous?
options: The vehicle will exceed the speed limit.
The vehicle will not have enough distance to stop safely in an emergency.
The engine may overheat because of restricted air flow over the vehicle's engine.
The braking system is less efficient in the slipstream of the vehicle in front.
allQuestions.explanation: If you drive too close to the vehicle in front and it brakes suddenly, you will not have enough time to react. For that reason you should always keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front. One way of calculating a safe distance in dry weather is the two- second rule: Allow at least two seconds to elapse between the vehicle in front and your own vehicle passing a fixed point such as a lamp post or sign post.

allQuestions.question: Is tailgating allowed on a motorway or dual carriageway?
options: Yes, because there is oncoming traffic.
Yes, because all traffic moves in the one direction at the same time.
No, because the vehicle in front may stop suddenly.
No, because other vehicles do not have room to overtake.
allQuestions.explanation: If you drive too close to the vehicle in front and it brakes suddenly, you will not have enough time to react. For that reason you should always keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front. One way of calculating a safe distance in dry weather is the two- second rule: Allow at least two seconds to elapse between the vehicle in front and your own vehicle passing a fixed point such as a lamp post or sign post.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do if another vehicle blocks their right of way at a junction?
options: Flash the headlights to express displeasure.
Pursue the vehicle and express displeasure.
Be patient and show restraint.
Sound the horn and flash the lights to show your frustration.
allQuestions.explanation: You should always try to show restraint. It is important to understand that the right of way is not an absolute right of way, and you must always proceed with caution and with regard for other road users. It's safer and more socially responsible.

allQuestions.question: A driver who is about to undertake a journey is upset or angry. What should they do?
options: A driver should not drive until they are calm.
Drive slower than normal for a distance.
Being upset or angry does not affect driving.
allQuestions.explanation: If you drive when you are angry or upset, you are more likely to be involved ina collision, and more likely to react to other drivers bad behaviour. Take the time to calm down and compose yourself before you set out on a journey.

allQuestions.question: When being overtaken and there is oncoming traffic, what should a driver do?
options: Speed up so the following vehicle cannot overtake.
Allow the overtaking vehicle to pass and return safely to the left side of the road.
Maintain position and flash the headlights to warn the oncoming traffic.
Maintain position because other drivers should not have attempted to overtake.
allQuestions.explanation: When you are being overtaken and there are oncoming vehicles, you should show consideration for all the other traffic and allow the overtaking vehicle to move in front of you to avoid the risk of a collision.

allQuestions.question: When another driver is in a hurry and cuts in front what should a driver do?
options: Be patient and do not react.
Drive faster to make up for lost time.
Drive closely behind them so other vehicles cannot do the same.
Flash the headlights to express their annoyance.
allQuestions.explanation: If another driver behaves badly, you should not let it annoy you - show restraint and don't react. Road rage only increases the risk of a collision.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver be aware of when driving through a section of road where roadworks are ongoing?
options: Narrower lanes than usual and restricted shoulder areas.
That road workers are always aware of the movement of traffic.
That the area will be cleared for the driver so that there are no traffic delays.
allQuestions.explanation: When travelling through a section of roadworks, a driver needs to be extra careful, as the road surface area may be considerably reduced. It may be narrower, uneven, slippery or there may be loose chippings which may pose a danger for road workers and other road users.

allQuestions.question: To whom should a driver report aggressive driving?
options: Health and Safety Authority.
Road Safety Authority.
Local Garda station or Traffic Watch.
Transport Infrastructure Ireland.
allQuestions.explanation: Report all aggressive driving incidents to Traffic Watch or a Garda station. They are the best people to deal with aggressive driving.

allQuestions.question: When driving on a cobblestone road why should you take extra care?
options: The road surface is particularly even and tyre grip is improved.
The smoothness of the cobblestones helps to improve grip.
The road surface is uneven and road grip varies.
The gaps between the stones helps road holding and grip is improved.
allQuestions.explanation: Different road surfaces can affect your vehicle's grip on the road and its stopping distances. You should be aware of this when driving on different surfaces.

allQuestions.question: Why must a driver be particularly careful here?
options: Because a vehicle could come from the left.
The vehicle coming from the right has the right of way.
Because there is an increased danger of skidding.
The vehicle coming from the right is not required to signal.
allQuestions.explanation: Where there are fallen leaves on the road surface, your tyres might have reduced grip on the road surface and your braking distances might be greater.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do if there is a large oil spill on the road?
options: Maintain normal speed in a lower gear and switch on hazard warning lights.
Depress the clutch and brake sharply and switch on the hazard warning lights.
Reduce speed by gently applying the brakes and switch on the hazard warning lights.
Maintain normal speed and try to drive on the spill with the wheels.
allQuestions.explanation: Where oil is spilt on the road, your tyres will have reduced grip, and you might be at risk of skidding if you brake sharply. If you do come across oil on the road, brake gently and switch on your hazard warning lights for a short period to alert other traffic to the hazard.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver be aware of before crossing railway or tram lines?
options: There may be an uneven surface and tyre grip may be reduced when crossing the rails.
The tyre grip may be improved crossing the rails.
The wheels may become caught in the rails, causing the tyres to deflate.
There may be a reduction in tyre noise while crossing the rails.
allQuestions.explanation: You should be aware of the impact of changes in the road surface. For example, at railway and tram crossings the uneven surface or oil deposits could reduce the grip of your tyres. Slow down as you approach railway or tram crossings and increase your distance from the vehicle in front.

allQuestions.question: What should drivers do if they approach road works and there is earth-moving machinery moving about?
options: Reduce speed as there may be loose gravel or mud on the road.
Stop, turn the vehicle around on the road and find an alternative route.
Switch on headlights as a warning and carry on as normal.
allQuestions.explanation: Where earth-moving machinery is working, there are likely to be mud and gravel deposits on the road. Also the noise of such machines might make it hard for road workers to hear the approaching traffic. When you come across earth-moving machinery, slow down and proceed with extreme caution.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do if they encounter loose chippings on a road?
options: Stop the vehicle until the loose chippings can be removed.
Slow down and allow extra clearance to other traffic.
A driver should press their hand against the windscreen.
Increase speed so as to avoid causing damage to the vehicle.
allQuestions.explanation: Where there are loose chippings on the road, you should slow down and comply with any reduced speed limit and leave extra room (or clearance) between your vehicle and other traffic. This will also give you more time to stop if you need to, and it will help to reduce the amount of chippings your vehicle throws up against other vehicles and possible injury to pedestrians.

allQuestions.question: What effect does spilt diesel have on a road?
options: It improves the vehicle's braking ability.
It makes the road more slippery.
It increases tyre noise.
allQuestions.explanation: Diesel spilt on the road can make the road surface extremely slippery, particularly if the road is wet.

allQuestions.question: When driving on a road with tram lines why should a driver take extra care?
options: Driving on the tracks can reduce tyre grip.
Driving on the tracks can improve braking.
Driving on the tracks can improve steering.
Driving on the tracks can improve tyre grip.
allQuestions.explanation: Different road surfaces can affect your vehicle's grip on the road and its stopping distances. You should be aware of this when driving on different surfaces.

allQuestions.question: When should a driver use dipped headlights?
options: When visibility is less than 200 metres.
From just after dusk to just before dawn.
When visibility is less than 300 metres.
From 00:00 hrs to 06:00 hrs.
allQuestions.explanation: Lighting up hours are defined as the period of time during which drivers should turn on dipped headlights in order to be seen. This period normally starts half an hour after sunset and ends half an hour before sunrise.

allQuestions.question: What lights should a vehicle show at dusk?
options: Daytime Running Lights (DRLs) only.
Full headlights.
Fog lights.
Dipped headlights.
allQuestions.explanation: Drivers need to see and be seen during all periods of low light levels - for example, at dusk and dawn and in some bad weather conditions. At times of low light, you should turn on dipped headlights. The Road Safety Authority recommends that motorcyclists and drivers turn on their dipped headlights or daytime running lights during daylight hours.

allQuestions.question: When driving at night the full headlights of a typical car should enable the driver to see for a distance of how many metres?
options: 150 metres.
50 metres.
100 metres.
200 metres.
allQuestions.explanation: At night in good driving conditions the full headlights of a car will typically let you see 100 metres ahead. So, you should travel at a speed that allows you to stop within that distance.

allQuestions.question: When driving at night the dipped headlights of a typical car should enable the driver to see for a distance of how many metres?
options: 40 metres.
30 metres.
50 metres.
20 metres.
allQuestions.explanation: When driving at night in good driving conditions the dipped headlights of a car will typically let you see 30 metres ahead. So, you should travel at a speed that allows you to stop in that distance.

allQuestions.question: What are the possible consequences of having incorrectly adjusted headlights?
options: The wattage of the headlights could be reduced.
The headlights could overheat.
Visibility could be increased.
Oncoming road users could be dazzled.
allQuestions.explanation: You are responsible for making sure that your vehicle is roadworthy and that its headlights are adjusted correctly. If the headlights are out of line they are less effective and may dazzle oncoming traffic, even when dipped.

allQuestions.question: When driving at night, when must a driver dip the vehicle's full headlights?
options: When meeting or driving behind other traffic.
When there is no oncoming traffic.
When driving at less than 50 km/h.
When entering a motorway.
allQuestions.explanation: When driving at night you should dip your headlights when you meet oncoming vehicles so that you do not dazzle them. And you should also dip your headlights when you are driving behind another vehicle so the driver is not dazzled by your lights in their mirror.

allQuestions.question: When driving at night and blinded by the lights of an oncoming vehicle, what should a driver do?
options: Repeatedly flash the headlights to warn the offending driver.
Drive well to the left and maintain normal speed.
Look towards the verge and slow down and stop if necessary.
Reduce speed and switch on the full headlights.
allQuestions.explanation: If you are dazzled by the lights of an oncoming vehicle, look towards the verge until the vehicle has passed. Slow down and stop if necessary.

allQuestions.question: A driver has been driving regularly in daylight and must now undertake a journey at night. What should the driver do?
options: Drive at a higher speed than during the day as traffic is lighter at night.
Drive at a higher speed than during the day to minimise the chances of falling asleep.
Drive at the same speed as during the day as there is no extra danger.
Drive at a slower speed than in the day as visibility is reduced at night.
allQuestions.explanation: If you are not familiar with driving at night time, it can take quite a while to adjust to conditions. For that reason, you might need to drive slower until you get used to the reduced visibility at night.

allQuestions.question: With regard to vehicle speed, what should a driver do when driving at night?
options: Maintain normal vehicle speed and drive with full headlights.
Drive at a higher speed than during the day to reduce the chances of falling asleep.
Increase vehicle speed as traffic is lighter at night.
Drive at a speed that enables the driver to stop within the distance ahead that they can see to be clear.
allQuestions.explanation: When driving at night in good driving conditions the full headlights of a car will typically let you see 100 metres ahead. So, you should travel at a speed that allows you to stop in that distance.

allQuestions.question: When driving at night, what is the safest approach for a driver to adopt?
options: Drive at a speed that enables the driver to stop within the distance ahead that they can see to be clear.
Drive at the maximum speed limit with full headlights on to see clearly ahead.
Drive at the maximum speed limit with dipped headlights on at all times.
Drive with full headlights on at all times.
allQuestions.explanation: When driving at night in good driving conditions the dipped headlights of a car will typically let you see 30 metres ahead. So, you should travel at a speed that allows you to stop in that distance.

allQuestions.question: When meeting an oncoming vehicle at night, what should a driver do?
options: Increase speed to pass the oncoming vehicle.
Avoid looking directly at the oncoming vehicle's lights.
Focus eyes directly on the oncoming vehicle's lights.
Focus eyes directly on the steering.
allQuestions.explanation: If you are dazzled by the lights of an oncoming vehicle, look towards the verge until the vehicle has passed and/or slow down and stop if necessary.

allQuestions.question: When is it safe for a driver to use the main beam headlights when driving at night?
options: When following a vehicle a short distance ahead.
This practice is not permitted.
When there is no oncoming traffic.
In built up areas where there is good street lighting.
allQuestions.explanation: Drivers should use the main beam headlights, to improve visibility, when driving at night in unlit rural areas - this will enable them to see as far ahead as possible. Making sure, however, that these lights are dimmed where necessary to avoid dazzling or inconveniencing other road users.

allQuestions.question: What lights should a driver have on when driving behind other traffic at night?
options: Dipped headlights.
Side lights.
Main beam headlights.
Front fog lights.
allQuestions.explanation: Drivers should dip their headlights when driving behind another vehicle so the driver in front is not dazzled by your lights in their mirror.

allQuestions.question: When driving at night, when must a driver use dipped headlights?
options: When meeting or driving behind other traffic.
When driving at more than 100 km/h.
When there is no oncoming traffic.
When driving at less than 50 km/h.
allQuestions.explanation: When driving at night drivers should dip their main beam headlights when meeting or following traffic to avoid dazzling or endangering other road users.

allQuestions.question: When dazzled by the lights of an oncoming vehicle, what should a driver do?
options: Shield their eyes with their hand.
Look at the dashboard momentarily.
Do not look directly at the lights.
Turn their head to the right.
allQuestions.explanation: If dazzled by the lights of an oncoming vehicle, do not look directly at the oncoming lights. Instead glance towards the verge until the vehicle has passed and/or slow down and stop if necessary. This will avoid any temporary blindness caused by the brightness of the oncoming lights.

allQuestions.question: Is a driver allowed to sound the horn while driving in a built-up area at night?
options: Yes, but between 11:30 pm and 7:00 am the horn may be sounded only in an emergency.
Yes, but only for momentary use.
No, use of the horn is not permitted in a built-up area between 11:30 pm and 7:00 am.
Yes, but only between 11:30 pm and 7:00 am.
allQuestions.explanation: Drivers are not allowed to use the horn in a built-up area between 11:30 pm and 7:00 am unless there is a traffic emergency. Only use a horn to warn other road users of danger or if needed to make them aware of your vehicle's presence for safety reasons. Using the horn does not give drivers an automatic right of way.  Never use the horn to provoke a reaction from or to rebuke another motorist.

allQuestions.question: When is the use of the horn prohibited?
options: Between 11:30 pm and 7:00 am in a built-up area.
Between 11:30 pm and 6:00 am on any road.
Between 10:00 pm and 6:00 am in a built-up area.
At all times in a built-up area.
allQuestions.explanation: Drivers are not permitted to sound the horn in a built-up area between 11:30 pm and 7:00 am unless there is a traffic emergency. Only sound the horn to warn other road users of oncoming danger or if they need to be made aware of your presence for safety reasons. Sounding the horn does not give the driver an automatic right of way. Never sound the horn to provoke a reaction from or to rebuke another motorist.

allQuestions.question: What should the driver allow for when following the bus on an icy road?
options: Same braking distance as in wet conditions.
A longer braking distance is required.
A shorter braking distance is required.
allQuestions.explanation: When driving in icy conditions, you should always reduce speed and allow a bigger gap to the vehicle in front in order to be able to stop safely if necessary.

allQuestions.question: What lights should a driver use in dense fog?
options: Front and rear fog lights along with hazard warning lights.
Front and rear fog lights along with side lights.
Front and rear fog lights along with main beam lights.
Front and rear fog lights along with dipped headlights.
allQuestions.explanation: When driving in dense fog you should switch on your front and rear fog lights along with dipped headlights. You should not drive in fog with main beam headlights on.

allQuestions.question: After a heavy downpour, why should a driver keep a greater distance from the vehicle in front?
options: Because wheels rotate at a greater speed after rain.
Because wheels rotate at a slower speed after rain.
Because wheel-spray may impair visibility.
Because required stopping distances are decreased.
allQuestions.explanation: Heavy rain can affect how well you can see and how well you can be seen by other road users. Because of that you should slow down in heavy rain and keep a greater distance from the vehicle in front.

allQuestions.question: What should the driver be aware of when crossing road markings such as lines and directional arrows in wet weather?
options: Steering control is improved.
The tyre grip is improved.
The required stopping distance is reduced due to improved tyre grip.
The required stopping distance is increased due to reduced tyre grip.
allQuestions.explanation: You should be aware of the impact of changes in the road surface. For example, road markings and directional arrows can become slippery when wet. Where  possible, avoid driving on road markings, and be aware of the increased risk of skidding.

allQuestions.question: How does rain affect driving in this situation?
options: It reduces the danger of skidding.
It increases the danger of skidding.
It increases tyre grip on the road.
It increases visibility.
allQuestions.explanation: When it is wet, your tyres do not grip the road surface as well as when it is dry, your stopping distance is increased and you are more likely to skid. For these reasons you should slow down during or after rain and keep a greater distance from the vehicle in front.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do when there are dark clouds and visibility is reduced during daylight hours?
options: Drive with dipped headlights switched on.
Keep close to any vehicle in front with headlights off.
Drive with main beam headlights switched on.
Driver should not switch on lights until lighting up hours.
allQuestions.explanation: Drivers need to see and be seen during all periods of low light levels - for example, at dusk and dawn and in some bad weather conditions. At times of low light, you should turn on dipped headlights.

allQuestions.question: What effect does a wet road surface have on a vehicle's braking ability?
options: It reduces the braking distance of that required on a dry surface.
It makes no difference to the required braking distance.
Generally, it doubles the braking distance of that required on a dry surface.
Modern tyres provide grip on a wet road as effectively as on a dry road.
allQuestions.explanation: When it is wet, your tyres do not grip the road surface as well as when it is dry and your stopping distance is increased. For these reasons you should slow down during or after rain and keep a greater distance from the vehicle in front.

allQuestions.question: What stopping distance should a driver allow for when driving in snow or icy conditions?
options: Up to ten times the normal distance.
Twice the normal distance.
The normal distance.
Up to half the normal distance.
allQuestions.explanation: When driving in snow or icy conditions a driver should allow a greater distance from the vehicle in front as stopping distances can be increased by up to ten times the normal.

allQuestions.question: Why does it take longer to stop the vehicle on a wet road?
options: The brake fluid is less effective in wet weather.
The tyres have less road grip than in dry weather.
The suspension of the vehicle is lighter in wet weather.
The tyres have more grip than in dry weather.
allQuestions.explanation: When driving on wet road surfaces the grip of your tyres is reduced which may lead to significantly longer stopping distances. Drivers should be aware of these conditions and reduce speed as stopping quickly may result in skidding.

allQuestions.question: What is the effect on the control of the vehicle if there is a film of water between the vehicle's tyres and the road surface?
options: Steering will be more effective.
Braking only will be less effective.
Steering and braking will be less effective.
Steering and braking will be more effective.
allQuestions.explanation: When driving on a road where there is a lot of surface water, a film of water can build up between the tyres and the road surface. When this occurs it is called aquaplaning, it reduces the grip of the tyres on the road and can result in the total loss of control over the vehicle's steering and braking.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do when driving in slippery road conditions?
options: Drive at lower speeds and use gentle acceleration and braking.
Maintain a normal distance from the vehicle in front.
Apply the brakes sharply from time to time to test the road surface.
Drive at normal speed but allow extra stopping distance.
allQuestions.explanation: When driving in slippery road conditions, drivers should be particularly smooth and gradual in the way they accelerate and brake. This will help to avoid skidding or slipping and helps to maintain control of the vehicle.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do when travelling downhill on snow or ice?
options: Select an appropriate gear and brake gently to control speed.
Use a higher gear than normal in order to avoid wheel spin.
Avoid using the brake and use a high gear.
Keep close to the left and brake sharply to reduce speed.
allQuestions.explanation: When travelling downhill in snow or ice, you should select a lower gear to take advantage of engine braking and use the brakes very gently when you need to.

allQuestions.question: In wet weather how might a driver judge what is a safe following distance from the vehicle in front?
options: By allowing four vehicle lengths between the vehicles.
By allowing two vehicle lengths between the vehicles.
By allowing at least two seconds to elapse between the vehicle in front and the driver's own vehicle passing a fixed point.
By allowing at least four seconds to elapse between the vehicle in front and the driver's own vehicle passing a fixed point.
allQuestions.explanation: In wet conditions you should maintain a gap of at least four seconds from the vehicle in front - at least twice as long as in dry conditions.

allQuestions.question: What lights should a driver use when driving in dense fog?
options: Drive with sidelights and hazard warning lights.
Drive with full headlights and fog lights.
Drive with dipped headlights and fog lights.
Drive with sidelights and fog lights.
allQuestions.explanation: In dense fog you should use dipped headlights and fog lights (where fitted). Sidelights are not strong enough in fog, and full headlights can reflect off the fog and make it harder to see where you are going.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do when driving in dense fog?
options: Reduce speed and use full headlights.
Reduce speed and use dipped headlights.
Drive along the central dividing line and watch for the reflective markings.
Drive along the hard shoulder and watch for the reflective markers.
allQuestions.explanation: In dense fog you should reduce your speed and use dipped headlights and fog lights (where fitted). Sidelights are not strong enough in fog, and full headlights can reflect off the fog and make it harder to see where you are going.

allQuestions.question: When should a driver use fog lights on their vehicle?
options: Use fog lights only in dense fog and falling snow.
Switch on fog lights as a warning to pedestrians.
Use fog lights on a badly lit country road.
Use fog lights to improve visibility during light rain.
allQuestions.explanation: A driver should use fog lights only during dense fog or falling snow. They must be switched off at all other times.

allQuestions.question: When can a driver expect to encounter black ice?
options: When the temperature drops close to freezing.
Black ice only occurs on motorways.
Only in the early hours of the morning.
Only late at night.
allQuestions.explanation: Black ice is an almost invisible and thin coating of ice on the surface of the road. Sometimes it can look like a sheet of water or as if the road is wet.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do if there is black ice on the road?
options: Apply the brakes regularly to prevent them from freezing.
Avoid harsh braking, steering and acceleration.
Apply the brakes regularly to check road surface.
Only use a low gear to improve traction.
allQuestions.explanation: If a driver suspects black ice, they should avoid harsh braking, steering and acceleration. This will help reduce the risk of skidding.

allQuestions.question: Where is black ice likely to occur on the road?
options: Only in built-up areas.
On a hard shoulder only.
In sheltered or shaded areas.
In mild weather on a coastal road.
allQuestions.explanation: Black ice occurs when moisture freezes on a very cold surface. Exposed roads and bridges can have black ice when other sections of the same road may be clear. Black ice is virtually invisible, and so presents a particular hazard for motorcyclists and drivers. allQuestions.question: What is the safest practice when driving on icy roads?
options: Rely completely on the ABS or other advanced driver assistance systems.
Drive at normal speed but apply the brakes from time to time to check for grip.
Drive at a slower speed than usual using gentle acceleration and braking.
Drive in a low gear at all times using maximum acceleration.
allQuestions.explanation: When driving on icy roads a driver should avoid harsh braking, steering and acceleration. This will help reduce the risk of skidding.

allQuestions.question: When driving, what effect could icy roads have on the vehicle?
options: Rear tyre pressure increases.
Tyre grip improves in lower temperatures.
The vehicle would be more likely to skid.
Front tyre pressure increases.
allQuestions.explanation: Icy roads can have a dramatic effect on the way a vehicle handles, and there can be an increased risk of skidding. When driving on icy roads a driver should avoid harsh braking, steering and acceleration. This will help reduce the risk of skidding.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do when driving in slippery road conditions?
options: Accelerate harder using only the lower gears.
Brake regularly to improve tyre grip.
Use gentle acceleration and braking.
Drive slower than normal keeping a close distance to the vehicle in front.
allQuestions.explanation: Tyres have less grip on the road when it is wet or icy. Slow down in slippery conditions, and keep a greater distance from the vehicle in front.

allQuestions.question: How should a driver manage a steep hill or humpbacked bridge when the road is slippery?
options: Select neutral gear position.
Press the clutch only.
Press the clutch and brake together.
Drive with extreme care.
allQuestions.explanation: Be extra careful when negotiating steep hills or humpbacked bridges in slippery conditions. Slow down gently on the approach, select the appropriate gear for the speed of the vehicle and use gentle steering and acceleration.

allQuestions.question: Apart from the risk of skidding, what should the driver be aware of when driving in snow?
options: The air in the tyres may freeze, causing them to burst.
The brake fluid may freeze, causing the brakes to fail.
Road signs and road markings may become obscured.
The power steering fluid may freeze causing the steering to fail.
allQuestions.explanation: Road signs and road markings may become obscured by snow. If this happens you may have difficulty reading regulatory, warning and information signs. This is the main reason why these signs are different shapes. Drivers should pay particular attention when travelling in these conditions.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do when driving in heavy rain?
options: Be aware that the vehicle may slide or 'aquaplane'.
Increase speed so that the vehicle will glide over any standing water.
Weave the vehicle slightly in order to improve tyre grip.
Maintain normal speeds as on a dry road.
allQuestions.explanation: On a wet road, a film of water can build up between the tyres and the road surface. This is called aquaplaning and it has the effect of reducing the grip of the tyres on the road, and this affects the steering and braking. For these reasons the driver should slow down during and after rain and keep a greater distance from the vehicle in front.

allQuestions.question: What is the danger in driving at high speeds on wet roads?
options: Danger that tyre pressure will automatically increase.
There is no danger provided that the tyre pressure has been increased to take account of weather conditions.
Danger of 'aquaplaning' or sliding across the road surface.
There is no danger provided that the tyre pressure has been reduced to take account of weather conditions.
allQuestions.explanation: The driver should moderate their speed during heavy rain or where water is building up on the road surface. This will help to avoid 'aquaplaning' which has the effect of reducing the grip of the tyres on the road, and this affects the steering and braking. For these reasons the driver should slow down during and after rain and keep a greater distance from the vehicle in front.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do after passing through a flooded section of road?
options: Apply the handbrake gradually to dry out the rear brakes only.
Increase the speed of the vehicle to dry out the brakes.
Apply the brake pedal lightly at slow speed for a short distance to dry the brakes.
Apply the brakes firmly to check if they are still effective.
allQuestions.explanation: When driving through a flooded section of road, brakes may become less effective. If this happens, test brakes to ensure that they have not been affected by the water - check mirrors before doing so. If they have been affected, press gently on the brake pedal when driving until they dry out and return to normal.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do where a section of road ahead has a shallow flooded area?
options: Decrease speed and use a higher gear.
Increase speed and use a higher gear.
Drive in a low gear as slowly as possible keeping the revs high.
Use a high gear and maintain the same speed keeping the engine revs low.
allQuestions.explanation: When approaching a stretch of road with shallow flooding, reduce speed and assess the area for any danger. When driving through surface water, drive in a low gear as slowly as possible keeping the revs high to avoid stalling.

allQuestions.question: After a heavy downpour, why should a driver keep a greater distance from the vehicle in front?
options: Because tyre grip improves when wet.
Because wheels rotate at a greater speed after rain.
Because wheels rotate at a slower speed after rain.
Because the required stopping distances is greater.
allQuestions.explanation: On a wet road surface, your tyres do not grip the road surface as well as in dry conditions and your required stopping distance is increased. Because of that you should slow down during or after rain and keep a greater distance from the vehicle in front.

allQuestions.question: In general, which of the following should a driver do before entering a tunnel?
options: Switch on hazard warning lights to alert other traffic of their presence.
Ensure that full headlights are switched on.
Only use dipped headlights if there is other traffic in the tunnel.
Ensure that dipped headlights are switched on.
allQuestions.explanation: In general, a driver should switch on their dipped headlights before entering a tunnel.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do when entering a tunnel?
options: Always switch off your radio to avoid distractions.
Keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front.
Drive closer to the vehicle in front.
Never drive below the posted speed limit.
allQuestions.explanation: The driver should keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front remembering that they are entering a tunnel and tailgating could create an emergency. The minimum recommended safe distance for a car or motor cycle is 50 metres and is 100 metres for all other vehicles. Always remember the 2 second rule.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do if there is very heavy traffic congestion in a tunnel?
options: Keep close to the vehicle in front.
Leave the vehicle.
Switch on hazard warning lights.
Stop at the nearest emergency exit.
allQuestions.explanation: If there is traffic congestion in a tunnel, you should switch on hazard lights and remain patient. Keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front even in slow-moving traffic. Listen for traffic messages on the tunnel radio station, if available.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do if traffic comes to a halt in a tunnel?
options: Select a low gear and keep the engine running.
Switch off the engine.
Switch on front and rear fog lights.
allQuestions.explanation: If traffic comes to a halt in a tunnel, switch off your engine to prevent a build up of fumes in the tunnel. Stay patient and follow the instructions of the tunnel operators.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do if their vehicle breaks down or they are involved in a collision in a tunnel?
options: Signal all other traffic to stop.
Beckon other traffic to overtake.
Switch off all lights and remain in vehicle until help arrives.
Switch on hazard warning lights and walk to emergency station to call for help.
allQuestions.explanation: If your vehicle breaks down or is involved in a collision in a tunnel, switch on your hazard warning lights, switch off your engine, go to an emergency station and use the emergency phone to alert the tunnel operator.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do if their vehicle breaks down in a tunnel?
options: Use the emergency telephone to call for help.
Walk to the end of the tunnel and call the Gardaí.
Wait in the vehicle until help arrives.
Flag down a passing motorist and ask for help.
allQuestions.explanation: If your vehicle breaks down or is involved in a collision in a tunnel, switch on your hazard warning lights, switch off your engine, go to an emergency station and use the emergency phone to alert the tunnel operator.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do in the event of a breakdown or incident in a tunnel?
options: Switch off the engine and switch on the hazard lights.
Reverse the vehicle if necessary to make room for overtaking traffic.
Beckon other traffic to overtake.
Signal the vehicle behind to stop and ask the driver to summon help at the other end of the tunnel.
allQuestions.explanation: If your vehicle breaks down or is involved in a collision in a tunnel, switch on your hazard warning lights, switch off your engine, go to an emergency station and use the emergency phone to alert the tunnel operator.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do if their vehicle goes on fire in a tunnel?
options: Leave the vehicle and use the fire extinguishers provided in the tunnel to extinguish the fire.
Leave the vehicle and follow the emergency escape route.
Drive to the nearest emergency station.
Drive to the nearest fire exit.
allQuestions.explanation: If your vehicle goes on fire in a tunnel, you should stop the vehicle as soon as possible, evacuate any passengers to a safe place, go to an emergency station and use the emergency phone to alert the tunnel operator.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do when they encounter mud on the road?
options: Gradually increase speed so that the mud on the road will not stick to the tyres.
Apply the brakes immediately and put on the hazard warning lights.
Reduce speed and be aware of farm or works vehicles on the road.
Change to a lower gear and pump the brakes to see how slippery the surface is.
allQuestions.explanation: Where there is mud on the road you should slow down and be aware that there is a danger of skidding. Your stopping distance will also be greater where there is mud on the road.

Engine revolution.
Oil level.
allQuestions.explanation: The rev counter measures the speed of the engine, in revolutions per minute. Generally, the higher the revs, the more fuel the engine is using, so drivers should keep an eye on the rev counter to help drive in a more eco-friendly manner.

allQuestions.question: What does a rev counter provide information on?
options: Engine revolutions.
Wheel revolutions.
Heater-fan revolutions.
Gear box revolutions.
allQuestions.explanation: The rev counter measures the speed of the engine, in revolutions per minute. Generally, the higher the revs, the more fuel the engine is using, so drivers should keep an eye on the rev counter to help drive in a more eco-friendly manner.

allQuestions.question: What does blue smoke coming from the vehicle's exhaust generally mean?
options: The catalytic converter is worn out.
The engine is overheating.
The engine is burning oil.
The air filter needs to be replaced.
allQuestions.explanation: A vehicle can give off blue smoke from the exhaust when it is burning oil. Poor maintenance and worn engines are typical causes. This blue smoke is harmful to the environment and may be costly. Drivers should have the vehicle checked by a competent person.

allQuestions.question: What is the effect of a worn exhaust?
options: Fuel efficiency is increased as the fumes escape more quickly.
The filtering of fumes is reduced and engine noise is louder.
Gear-changing is more difficult.
The engine overheats.
allQuestions.explanation: A worn exhaust system can have a number of effects, including increased noise from the engine and more environmentally damaging fumes (as they are not filtered properly). There are requirements to ensure vehicles are compliant with EU and Irish legislation. Vehicles are tested for compliance during road worthiness testing.

allQuestions.question: What effect can a faulty exhaust system have?
options: It can increase wear on the vehicle's engine.
It can reduce the vehicle's engine noise.
It can improve the vehicle's fuel consumption.
It can increase the vehicle's noise and pollution levels.
allQuestions.explanation: A worn exhaust system can have a number of negative effects, including increased noise from the engine and more environmentally damaging fumes (as they are not filtered properly). There are requirements to ensure vehicles are compliant with EU and Irish legislation. Vehicles are tested for compliance during road worthiness testing.

allQuestions.question: What is the purpose of a catalytic converter?
options: It increases engine power.
It decreases engine power.
It filters exhaust gases and reduces air pollution.
It allows the engine to quickly reach its normal operating temperature.
allQuestions.explanation: The purpose of a catalytic converter (CAT) is to remove toxic or polluting gases such as carbon monoxide, nitrogen oxide and unburned hydrocarbons from the exhaust emissions. When the CAT is faulty, an engine management warning light illuminates on the dashboard and drivers should seek advice from a competent person.

allQuestions.question: How does harsh acceleration affect fuel consumption?
options: Fuel consumption decreases.
There is no effect provided the engine is properly tuned.
Fuel consumption increases.
There is no effect if a high gear is engaged.
allQuestions.explanation: Harsh acceleration increases fuel consumption. Smooth acceleration helps to reduce fuel consumption and the emissions from vehicles. Try not to over-rev the engine and use the appropriate gear for the speed of the vehicle. When slowing down, take your foot off the accelerator and allow the vehicle to slow progressively before you brake.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do to minimise fuel consumption in their vehicle?
options: Use gentle acceleration and braking.
Use maximum acceleration between gear changes.
Drive gently in a low gear.
allQuestions.explanation: Driving smoothly will help reduce fuel consumption. Read the road ahead and adjust speed in good time, and avoid harsh acceleration and late braking.

allQuestions.question: How does continuous high-speed driving affect fuel consumption?
options: It reduces fuel consumption as long as the road is straight.
It increases fuel consumption.
It uses the same consumption of fuel as lower speed driving.
It reduces fuel consumption.
allQuestions.explanation: Driving at continuous high speeds increases your fuel consumption. Vehicles driving at 112 km/h consumes approximately 30% more fuel than a vehicle travelling at 80 km/h.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do to ensure better fuel efficiency from their vehicle?
options: Ensure that the vehicle is regularly serviced.
Ensure that heavier items are carried at the rear of the vehicle.
Drive at higher speeds in order to reduce the time spent on the road.
Ensure any load carried is equally distributed on the vehicle.
allQuestions.explanation: One of the keys to good fuel efficiency is making sure that your vehicle is well maintained. Servicing should be carried out as recommended by the manufacturer. Checking the tyre pressure regularly can also help ensure good fuel efficiency.

allQuestions.question: How can fuel efficiency be improved?
options: By using an anti-waxing agent only in freezing conditions.
By using gentle acceleration and making gear changes appropriate to speed.
By accelerating hard up through the gears to reach the desired speed as quickly as possible.
By driving the vehicle in a lower gear for as long as possible.
allQuestions.explanation: A driver can contribute to their vehicle's fuel efficiency by reading the road ahead and driving smoothly. This is achieved by accelerating gently, using the most appropriate gear for the speed they are travelling at and avoiding harsh braking.

allQuestions.question: What effect does a worn exhaust have on a vehicle?
options: It causes noise and gas pollution levels to increase.
It causes the water coolant to leak from the engine.
It decreases fuel consumption.
It causes oil to leak on the road.
allQuestions.explanation: A vehicle with a worn exhaust will probably be noisier and will produce more polluting emissions. There are strict regulations governing the noise and emission levels of vehicles, and these are rigorously checked during a vehicle's NCT.

allQuestions.question: In what way do motor vehicles harm the environment?
options: By increasing carbon monoxide levels.
By decreasing radon levels.
By decreasing carbon monoxide levels.
By increasing radon levels.
allQuestions.explanation: Carbon monoxide is a poisonous gas emitted by vehicle exhausts into the atmosphere. Driving economically and keeping a vehicle well maintained can reduce the level of carbon monoxide emissions.

allQuestions.question: What can a driver do to maximise fuel efficiency while driving?
options: Increase road speed.
Fit a roof rack.
Reduce pressure in all tyres.
Avoid carrying unnecessary weight.
allQuestions.explanation: The more extra weight is in your vehicle, the more fuel you use. Using a roof rack or a roof box increases wind resistance and this also increases fuel consumption - by as much as 15%. Remove roof racks and roof boxes when not in use.

allQuestions.question: Which action is likely to cause an increase in fuel consumption?
options: Driving at a constant speed.
Turning off air conditioning.
Harsh acceleration.
Looking ahead and anticipating traffic flow.
allQuestions.explanation: Harsh acceleration increases fuel consumption. Driving smoothly reduces wear and tear and also improves fuel consumption. Use the highest gear possible without causing the engine to labour.

allQuestions.question: What alternatives can drivers take to help protect the environment?
options: Only use low gears.
Accelerate and brake harshly while driving.
Use public transport.
allQuestions.explanation: Using public transport helps to protect the environment. Buses, trams and trains are a more environmentally friendly way to move large numbers of people especially in urban areas. Consider using public transport where possible - not only is it more environmentally friendly, but it can also be more cost-effective when you take the cost of fuel and parking charges into account.

allQuestions.question: What can be achieved by the driving style known as 'Eco-Driving'?
options: Increased journey times.
Increased fuel consumption.
Reduced fuel consumption.
Reduced journey times.
allQuestions.explanation: The advantages of eco-driving include improved road safety, improved fuel consumption and reduced emissions. The eco-conscious driver becomes a more efficient driver because they learn to read the road further ahead and display better anticipation skills. This reduces the need for harsh acceleration and braking which results in a more economical style of driving and a smoother drive.

allQuestions.question: Which action contributes to eco-driving?
options: Braking harshly.
Fitting a roof rack.
Driving in a low gear at high speed.
Selecting a high gear as soon as possible.
allQuestions.explanation: Eco-driving contributes to road safety and also reduces fuel consumption and harmful emissions. allQuestions.question: What should drivers do if they become drowsy while driving?
options: Turn up the heating.
Stop, take a break including a short walk if possible.
Open a window or turn on the air conditioning to let cool air into the vehicle.
Stop and have a good meal to boost energy levels.
allQuestions.explanation: Driving when you are tired can be very dangerous, and tiredness is one of the main  causes of serious road collisions. If you become drowsy while driving, stop in a safe place and take a short nap. Then get some fresh air and stretch your legs for a few  minutes before setting off again. Taking a caffeine-based drink such as coffee may also help.

allQuestions.question: What should the driver do if they are driving and feel tired?
options: The driver should drive along the centre of the road and reduce speed.
The driver should stop and take a break.
The driver should drive on the hard shoulder where available.
allQuestions.explanation: Driving when you are tired can be very dangerous, and it may cause you to micro- sleep (or nod off momentarily). At 100 km/h you travel at 28 metres a second, so if you micro-sleep for just 4 seconds you would travel over 100 metres without being in control of the vehicle. Never drive if you are fighting sleep.

allQuestions.question: What effect does alcohol have on driver behaviour?
options: It slows down a driver's reactions.
It can increase perception and awareness.
It can reduce a driver's confidence.
It does not affect driver behaviour or ability.
allQuestions.explanation: Alcohol is a major factor in collisions that can lead to death and injury. Even small amounts of alcohol affect your judgement and ability to drive.

allQuestions.question: What effect does drinking alcohol have on a driver?
options: It increases concentration.
It improves coordination.
It reduces concentration.
It increases awareness.
allQuestions.explanation: Alcohol is a major factor in collisions that lead to death and injury. Even small amounts of alcohol affect your judgement, your concentration and your ability to react to hazards. A driver should never ever drink and drive.

allQuestions.question: If a motorist or a motorcyclist is taking medication which may affect their driving, what should they do?
options: Drive for short distances only.
Drive slower when under the influence of medication that affects driving.
Drink plenty of water while driving.
Seek medical advice in relation to driving.
allQuestions.explanation: Some medication can affect a driver's ability to drive safely. If you are on medication of any kind, you should ask your doctor or pharmacist to tell you if it is safe to drive while taking it. Read the patient information leaflet supplied with the medication.

allQuestions.question: When driving late at night what should a driver be aware of?
options: That speed limits do not apply between midnight and 6:00 am.
That all pedestrians will be wearing high-visibility clothing.
That there is a danger of themselves or other drivers falling asleep.
That trucks may drive in the outside lane of a motorway.
allQuestions.explanation: Driving when tired can be very dangerous and driver fatigue is one of the main causes of serious road collisions. 2 years.
1 year.

allQuestions.question: Which of the following is a possible consequence for a learner driver if they drive after drinking as little as just one unit of alcohol?
options: A €90 fine.
A €60 fine.
A three month disqualification from driving.
A one month disqualification from driving.
allQuestions.explanation: The blood alcohol concentrate limit for novice/learner drivers is much lower than that of a driver who has held their full licence for more than two years (not a novice driver). allQuestions.question: What is the maximum disqualification period imposed in court when the learner driver has a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) level in excess of 80 mg?
options: One year.
Four years.
Six years.
Two years.
allQuestions.explanation: Where a learner driver has failed to pay a fixed penalty notice they will be summonsed to court where a judge can apply a disqualification period of between 1-6 years.

allQuestions.question: What are the drink driving penalties for a learner driver with a blood alcohol concentrate (BAC) of 20 mg to 80 mg per 100 millilitres of blood?

€200 fine and 5 penalty points.
