allQuestions.question: What are the drink driving penalties for a driver with a blood alcohol concentrate (BAC) of 80 mg to 100 mg per 100 millilitres of blood?
options: €400 fine and 6 months driving disqualification.
€400 fine and 3 months driving disqualification.
€200 fine and 3 months driving disqualification.
€200 fine and 6 months driving disqualification.
allQuestions.explanation: Alcohol is a major factor in crashes that lead to death and injury. Research proves that even small amounts of alcohol affect your judgement and ability to drive. It is illegal to drive with alcohol levels above the legal limits.

allQuestions.question: What is the penalty for a driver who refuses to give breath, blood or urine samples as evidence for a second offence to An Gárda Síochána?
options: Automatic disqualification for 4 years.
Automatic disqualification for 6 years.
Automatic disqualification for 3 months.
Automatic disqualification for 12 months.
allQuestions.explanation: Alcohol is a major factor in crashes that lead to death and injury. Research proves that even small amounts of alcohol or drugs affect your judgement and ability to drive. It is illegal to drive with alcohol levels above the legal limits, or while under the influence of drugs. It is an offence to refuse to give a breath, blood or urine sample.

allQuestions.question: Can An Gárda Síochána conduct roadside testing for drugs and alcohol in the mornings?
options: They can check for drugs only.
No, they can't check until after midday.
Yes, they can check at any time.
They can check for alcohol only.
allQuestions.explanation: It is against the law to drive a car, motor bike, truck, bus, pedal bike or an animal- drawn vehicle while 'under the influence of an intoxicant to such an extent as to be incapable of having control of the vehicle’. Intoxicants include alcohol and drugs, whether taken separately or together. The word 'drugs' here includes legal prescribed and Over-The-Counter (OTC) medicines.

allQuestions.question: Along with an impairment test, what may a Garda request if they suspect a driver of driving under the influence of drugs?
options: A driver's licence.
A saliva sample.
A breath sample.
An insurance certificate.
allQuestions.explanation: If a driver is stopped at a roadside check, they should be aware that, along with the impairment test, Gardai can also request a saliva sample if they suspect the driver is driving under the influence of drugs.

allQuestions.question: What is the maximum penalty on conviction for drug driving?
options: €3,000 fine and 12 months driving disqualification.
€3,000 fine and 12 months in prison.
€5,000 fine and 6 months in prison.
€5,000 fine and 6 months driving disqualification.
allQuestions.explanation: Drivers should be aware of the severe penalties if they chose to drive having taken drugs and are detected. Drug driving is extremely dangerous due to the effect drugs have on the brain.

allQuestions.question: Do the limits for drink and drug driving differ if detected in the morning?
options: No, they are the same at all times.
No, unless tested after 10:00 am.
Yes, they are lower in the mornings.
Yes, they are higher in the evening.
allQuestions.explanation: The limits for drink and drug driving do not change depending on the time of the day drivers are checked. Drink and drugs remain in the body for a period of time. A driver should think carefully before driving a vehicle the morning after taking drink or drugs, and be aware that they could still be well over the limit.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do if they feel tired before starting a journey?
options: Open the windows in the vehicle before they start their journey.
Do not start the journey until they are rested.
Bring a cup of strong coffee to drink in the vehicle during the journey.
allQuestions.explanation: A driver should not drive or begin a journey if they are feeling tired or fatigued. Research has shown that tired drivers are a major road safety risk, both to themselves and to others.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do if they experience micro-sleep whilst driving?
options: Have a 20 minute sleep when they reach their destination.
Stop in a safe place.
Open all vehicle windows to reduce temperature.
allQuestions.explanation: A driver should not drive while tired or fatigued. Research has shown that tired drivers are a major road safety risk, both to themselves and to others. If a driver is tired and fighting sleep, they are likely to experience "micro-sleeps" these episodes can last up to 10 seconds and can be experienced even when eyes are open. allQuestions.question: What should a driver do if they are taking a medication which can make them feel drowsy?
options: Continue driving until they begin to feel drowsy.
Only drive during daylight hours.
Do not drive a vehicle.
allQuestions.explanation: It is against the law to drive a vehicle while under the influence of an intoxicant to such an extent as to be incapable of having control of the vehicle. Intoxicants include alcohol or drugs, whether taken separately or together. Drugs include legally prescribed or Over-The-Counter (OTC) medicines.

allQuestions.question: Subject to the speed limit, what is the 'safest' speed to drive at?
options: A driver should always try to drive at the speed limit for the road that they are on.
The speed that will enable the driver to stop the vehicle within the distance ahead that they can see to be clear.
A driver should always try to drive at the speed of other road users, regardless of the speed limit.
The speed of the slowest vehicle on the road.
allQuestions.explanation: You should always drive at a speed that allows you to stop within the distance that you can see to be clear ahead. If you don't think you could safely bring the vehicle to a stop within the range of what you can see, then you're driving too fast - slow down.

allQuestions.question: What is the recommended minimum stopping distance for a car travelling at 50 km/h on a dry road?
options: 55 metres.
15 metres.
5 metres.
25 metres.
allQuestions.explanation: The total minimum stopping distance of a vehicle depends on four things: Perception time, reaction time, the vehicle's speed and the vehicle's braking capability. The recommend minimum stopping distance of a car driving at 50 km/h under dry conditions is 25 metres.

allQuestions.question: What is the recommended minimum stopping distance for a car travelling at 50 km/h on a wet road?
options: 36 metres.
16 metres.
56 metres.
76 metres.
allQuestions.explanation: The total minimum stopping distance of a vehicle depends on four things: Perception time, reaction time, the vehicle's speed and the vehicle's braking capability. The recommend minimum stopping distance of a car driving at 50 km/h under wet conditions is 36 metres.

allQuestions.question: What is the recommended minimum stopping distance for a car travelling at 100 km/h on a dry road?
options: 120 metres.
30 metres.
90 metres.
70 metres.
allQuestions.explanation: The total minimum stopping distance of a vehicle depends on four things: Perception time, reaction time, the vehicle's speed and the vehicle's braking capability. The recommend minimum stopping distance of a car driving at 100 km/h under dry conditions is 70 metres.

allQuestions.question: Which of the following affects the braking distance of a vehicle?
options: The speed and weight of the vehicle.
The use of unleaded fuel.
The power of the engine.
The brake-pad clearance.
allQuestions.explanation: The overall stopping distance of your vehicle depends on its speed and weight - faster and heavier vehicles require greater stopping distances.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do when joining a motorway from a slip road?
options: Try to match the vehicle speed to that of traffic already on the motorway and merge into it in a suitable gap.
Drive directly onto the motorway as the driver on the acceleration lane has right of way.
Always stop at the end of the acceleration lane and yield to traffic on the motorway.
Drive along the hard shoulder until a suitable gap appears in the motorway traffic to allow the driver to merge into it.
allQuestions.explanation: When joining a motorway a driver should try to match their speed to that of the motorway traffic and merge into it when a suitable gap appears, avoiding driving in the hard shoulder, while yielding to traffic already on the motorway.

allQuestions.question: When driving on a motorway, what should a driver do if they miss their exit?
options: Wait on the hard shoulder until a suitable gap appears in traffic from both directions and then cross to the opposite side of the motorway.
Leave the motorway at the next exit and cross to the other side using the fly-over (or underpass).
Cross to the opposite side of the motorway when there is a suitable gap in the oncoming traffic.
Stop on the hard shoulder, switch on their hazard lights and reverse back to the desired exit.
allQuestions.explanation: If a driver misses their intended exit when driving on a motorway, they should proceed to the next junction exit where they can leave the motorway and then rejoin it on the opposite side of the motorway.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do when entering a slip road after leaving a motorway?
options: Comply with the speed limit on the road the driver is joining.
Always reduce speed gradually for a few kilometres.
There is never a need to adjust speed when on a slip road.
Brake severely when entering the slip road in order to slow down.
allQuestions.explanation: When a driver is leaving a motorway, they should enter the deceleration lane and reduce their speed. They should comply with the speed limit of the road they are entering.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do if they drive past their intended exit by mistake?
options: Use the emergency telephone to ask for advice.
Stop on the hard shoulder and reverse back to the exit.
Drive on and leave at the next exit.
Carefully complete a U-turn.
allQuestions.explanation: If a driver misses their intended exit when driving on a motorway, they should proceed to the next junction exit where they can leave the motorway and then rejoin it in the opposite direction.

allQuestions.question: What is the main difference between driving on a motorway and driving on other types of road?
options: Traffic is generally permitted to travel at a higher speed on a motorway.
Learner permit holders must be accompanied by a full licence holder.
Traffic generally travels at lower speeds on a motorway than on a dual-carriageway.
Traffic travelling at 120 km/h must only use the outside lane of a motorway.
allQuestions.explanation: Motorways are designed so that traffic can move faster and more freely, without traffic lights, crossroads, level crossings and other road features that might slow down traffic. There are also restrictions on who may use a motorway - for example learner-drivers and motorcycles under 50 cc are prohibited.

allQuestions.question: On a 2-lane motorway, what procedure should a driver adopt when wishing to overtake another vehicle safely?
options: Use their mirrors, signal and overtake in the right-hand lane when it is safe to do so.
Signal, use their mirrors and overtake in any available lane when it is safe to do so.
Use their mirrors, signal and overtake in the left-hand lane only.
Check for following traffic and overtake in either lane.
allQuestions.explanation: When a driver wants to overtake on a motorway, they should generally only overtake on the right unless traffic is travelling in slow moving queues. allQuestions.question: When can a driver travel in the right-hand lane on a dual carriageway?
options: When overtaking a vehicle in the left-hand lane.
In order to keep a greater distance from the hard shoulder.
When following other traffic in the right-hand lane.
allQuestions.explanation: You must normally drive in the left-hand lane of a dual carriageway. You should not use the right-hand lane as a driving lane. You may use the right-hand lane when overtaking or when intending to turn right a short distance ahead.

allQuestions.question: When should a driver move into an auxiliary lane on a motorway?
options: To leave the motorway.
To overtake slower traffic in other lanes.
To allow other traffic to overtake.
allQuestions.explanation: Auxiliary lanes are found on some motorways and are to the left of the main motorway lanes. They link the off-ramp of the road you are leaving with the next available off-ramp or exit. If a driver is already in lane 1 of the motorway and they intend to take the next exit, they should enter the auxiliary lane to do so. allQuestions.question: What is the correct action to take in this situation?
options: Keep a close eye on the children and be prepared to brake in good time.
Drive closer to the left-hand side (nearside) and sound the horn.
Continue to drive at the same speed.
allQuestions.explanation: Because it is difficult to predict children's behaviour, you should always be prepared to react to a change in the traffic situation or to stop.

allQuestions.question: What should the driver do when approaching this situation?
options: The driver should maintain current speed and reduce distance from the silver car.
The driver should be prepared for the vehicle in front to increase speed.
The driver may overtake the car and the girl as the road is marked with a broken white line.
Reduce speed and remain ready to brake since the girl on the footpath could suddenly cross the road.
allQuestions.explanation: It is often difficult to predict other road users behaviour. You should be prepared in case the pedestrian steps onto the road and the silver car stops suddenly.

allQuestions.question: When should a driver use the vehicle's rear view mirror?
options: Before switching on the rear demister.
Before reversing only.
Before moving off only.
Before changing direction.
allQuestions.explanation: You should use your mirrors to stay aware of traffic situations behind and around you. Always check your mirror before you change direction on a road, and before you signal or begin a manoeuvre.

allQuestions.question: How should a driver proceed if their view is blocked at a junction?
options: Ask a passer-by for guidance onto the other road.
Move out slowly onto the road while watching carefully for other traffic.
Sound the horn several times and proceed.
Flash headlights on and off before moving out.
allQuestions.explanation: At junctions where the view is blocked, move carefully into a position where you can see without interfering with other road users. Then assess the situation before you continue.

allQuestions.question: Where are the blind spots that a driver needs to be aware of when towing a loaded trailer?
options: The goods or cargo area on the back of the trailer.
The area to the side and rear of the vehicle and the trailer that the driver cannot see.
Parts of the road ahead which are blocked by other large vehicles.
The view to the front hidden by the sun-visor.
allQuestions.explanation: A blind spot is an area that a driver cannot see when looking forward or when looking in the mirrors. You should check your blind spots before changing direction or changing lane. The bigger the vehicle, the bigger the blind spots, and you should keep this in mind if you are driving behind a large vehicle, such as one towing a loaded trailer. allQuestions.question: What should a driver who wishes to perform a U-turn do?
options: Only perform a U-turn outside the urban speed limit area.
Check behind for approaching traffic and signal them to stop.
Check that the road is not one way.
Check ahead for approaching traffic and signal them to stop.
allQuestions.explanation: If you want to do a U-turn you must first choose a place where it is safe and legal to do it. Check all around for other road users and do not impede their right of way. Complete the manoeuvre efficiently and safely.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do who wishes to turn a vehicle around on the road?
options: Drive onto a footpath if necessary in order to ensure that they have enough room to turn.
Check ahead and behind for oncoming traffic and turn the vehicle around while still keeping a look out.
It is not allowed to turn a vehicle around on the road in any circumstance.
Drive into somebody's driveway and reverse back onto the road.
allQuestions.explanation: If you want to turn a vehicle around on the road, you must first choose a place where it is safe and legal to do so. Check all around for other road users and do not impede their right of way. Complete the manoeuvre efficiently and safely.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do when they want to safely change to the lane on the right in which there is other traffic?
options: Use the mirror, signal and move into the right-hand lane when a suitable gap appears in the traffic in that lane.
Pull in and stop, wait until a suitable gap appears and then move out to the right-hand lane.
Increase speed until travelling at the same speed as the traffic in the right lane, then move over and check mirrors.
Move gradually into the right-hand lane, indicate and then check mirrors.
allQuestions.explanation: Any time you change lanes, you should use the Mirror-Signal-Mirror (blind spots) - Manoeuvre routine. Check your mirrors, signal your intention, check your mirrors again (and your blind spots), and when a suitable gap becomes available manoeuvre the vehicle into the next lane, giving way to traffic already in that lane.

allQuestions.question: What should the driver be able to see in the vehicle mirrors when they are properly adjusted?
options: The area behind and to each side of the vehicle.
The passenger area of the vehicle.
The position of all the wheels.
The position of the left-side wheels.
allQuestions.explanation: Properly adjusted vehicle mirrors enable drivers to see the road behind and to the sides. This helps drivers to take into account what's happening behind them, so that they can make informed, correct and safer decisions.

allQuestions.question: What should the driver be able to see in the exterior mirrors of a vehicle when they are properly adjusted?
options: The sides of the vehicle only.
The area to each side of the vehicle.
60% angled to the vehicle and 40% to the road.
The back of the vehicle only.
allQuestions.explanation: Exterior mirrors enable drivers to see the area on each side of the vehicle. Drivers must take into account all visible hazards in order to make informed, correct and safer decisions.

allQuestions.question: The vehicle's exterior mirrors are covered by a film of mud and dust. What should the driver do?
options: Drive in the slip stream of other traffic, as this will eventually clean the mirrors.
Continue on and clean them after reaching the destination.
Angle the mirrors towards the front for a distance in order to clean them.
Clean them with a cloth or tissue before starting their journey.
allQuestions.explanation: The purpose of mirrors is to increase the driver's view to the rear and sides of the vehicle and to enable them to take into account all visible hazards. Proper use will enable drivers to make informed, correct and safer decisions. Drivers should ensure that all mirrors, including the exterior ones, are clean and properly adjusted at all times to ensure optimum view.

allQuestions.question: What effect can wet weather have on a vehicle's exterior mirrors?
options: Water droplets help to keep them clean.
Water droplets can obscure the reflected image.
Water can cause a short-circuit in the electrically heated mirrors.
Water droplets can make the reflected object appear closer than it really is.
allQuestions.explanation: When driving in wet weather conditions, small water droplets can form on the glass of the exterior mirrors. This could make it more difficult to see the road behind and to the sides. Switch on the mirror demisters, if they are fitted. If necessary, stop and clear them.

allQuestions.question: When may you pass another vehicle on the left-hand side?
options: When a driver cannot pass on the right-hand side because of oncoming traffic.
When the vehicle in front is signalling to turn right or in slow moving lanes of traffic.
A driver must never overtake on the left.
When there is enough space to do so.
allQuestions.explanation: Normally you must overtake on the right. There are, however, circumstances where you may overtake on the left - for example, when the vehicle has moved out and signalled to turn right.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do when overtaking parked vehicles in a residential area?
options: Allow enough clearance when passing.
Keep close to the parked vehicles allowing maximum room for oncoming traffic.
Increase speed to overtake the vehicles as quickly as possible.
Move as far to the right as possible.
allQuestions.explanation: When you are passing parked vehicles in a residential area, move into a safe overtaking position in good time and leave plenty of clearance between your vehicle and the parked vehicles to increase visibility of small children in the area and in case someone opens their car door in front of you.

allQuestions.question: When overtaking a cyclist what should a driver be aware of?
options: The cyclist may suddenly change direction.
The cyclist is not wearing a safety helmet.
The cyclist is only permitted to use the bus lane.
allQuestions.explanation: Cyclists are just as entitled to use the road as other vehicles, and drivers need to pay special attention to them. Cyclists are vulnerable road users and sometimes make sudden movements - for example, to avoid a pothole, some broken glass or other debris on the road. Sufficient clearance should be given when overtaking them to lessen the possible danger.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver ensure when overtaking a cyclist?
options: Overtake when the cyclist pulls in and stops.
Overtake only when the cyclist is in a cycle lane.
Overtake giving them plenty of space.
allQuestions.explanation: Cyclists are vulnerable road users. Motorists must give good clearance when overtaking cyclists.

allQuestions.question: Is a driver allowed to exceed the speed limit when overtaking?
options: The driver may exceed the speed limit briefly in order to complete the manoeuvre.
The driver may not exceed the speed limit when overtaking.
The driver may exceed the speed limit if the vehicle in front is turning left.
allQuestions.explanation: When overtaking the driver is not permitted to exceed the speed limit.

allQuestions.question: When is a driver allowed to overtake another vehicle on the left?
options: A driver is never allowed to overtake on the left.
When on the motorway in fast moving traffic.
When the driver is turning left.
allQuestions.explanation: Drivers must normally overtake on the right however they may overtake on the left when they have signalled that they intend to turn left and it is done in a safe manner relative to the traffic conditions.

allQuestions.question: When approaching a roundabout, to whom should a driver give way?
options: The driver approaching the roundabout always has right of way.
The driver must give way to traffic approaching from the right or already on the roundabout.
The driver must only give way to pedestrians and cyclists on the roundabout.
allQuestions.explanation: Drivers should always approach roundabouts with caution. They should be prepared to give way to traffic on the right, traffic already on the roundabout, pedestrians already crossing and to always stop if necessary.

allQuestions.question: In what direction should a driver turn when entering a roundabout?
options: To the right.
To either left or right.
To the right when controlled by a traffic light.
To the left.
allQuestions.explanation: By law you must enter a roundabout by turning to the left and giving way to traffic already on the roundabout.

allQuestions.question: In general, where two lanes are provided on the approach to a roundabout, which lane should a driver select when they intend taking an exit to the right (past the 12 o'clock position) of the roundabout?
options: By straddling both lanes.
The left-hand lane.
Either lane.
The right-hand lane.
allQuestions.explanation: When a driver approaches a roundabout where two lanes are provided, they should choose the most suitable one based on the road markings and the exit they intend to take off the roundabout. The left lane is generally used for vehicles exiting to the left (9 o'clock) or straight ahead (12 o'clock) and the right is for vehicles exiting at any exit after 12 o'clock.

allQuestions.question: What position should a driver generally adopt on approach to a roundabout when intending to take the first exit to the left?
options: Approach by straddling both lanes.
Approach in the right-hand lane.
Approach in any lane available.
Approach in the left-hand lane.
allQuestions.explanation: When a driver intends to take any exit between the 6 o'clock and 12 o'clock positions they should generally approach the roundabout in the left lane unless road markings dictate otherwise.

allQuestions.question: As the driver of the car, which conduct is correct?
options: A driver must drive on the right-hand side to allow clearance to the motorcyclist.
A driver must give way to traffic on the left.
Slow down and beckon the motorcyclist to cross the road.
A driver may proceed with caution.
allQuestions.explanation: You may proceed, but you should be aware of the presence of the motorcyclist. You should always be prepared to react to a change in the traffic situation - for example, the motorcyclist might not have seen your vehicle.

allQuestions.question: What should the driver do in this situation?
options: The driver may proceed onto the roundabout in front of the yellow car.
As the driver is entering the roundabout they have right of way.
The driver must yield to the yellow car on the roundabout.
The driver must wait for the yellow car to stop.
allQuestions.explanation: When you reach the roundabout, you must give way to traffic approaching from the right - unless signs, road markings or traffic lights tell you otherwise.

allQuestions.question: What should the driver do in this situation?
options: The driver must allow the red car to proceed.
The driver must stop and allow all other traffic to proceed.
The driver must allow the blue car to proceed.
The driver may turn in front of the other two cars.
allQuestions.explanation: When you are turning right from a major road to a minor road, you must yield to oncoming traffic and only proceed when it is safe to do so. However, the drivers on the minor roads must give way to the traffic on the major road.

allQuestions.question: What should the driver do in this situation?
options: The driver may continue ahead with caution.
The driver must allow the van to cross the junction.
The cyclist must allow the other vehicles to proceed.
The cyclist must proceed first.
allQuestions.explanation: On approaching a crossroads you should check the road sign to see which traffic has priority and be prepared for emerging traffic from either side. Vehicles do not have an automatic right of way on the road. The overriding rule is to proceed with caution in all circumstances.

allQuestions.question: What should the driver do in this situation?
options: The driver must turn left.
The driver must allow the orange car to cross.
The driver is not allowed to turn right.
The driver may turn right.
allQuestions.explanation: You may turn right if there no oncoming traffic but you should also be aware that there might be traffic emerging from the minor roads.

allQuestions.question: What should the driver do in this situation?
options: The driver may proceed first.
The driver must allow the blue truck to proceed.
The driver must allow the red car to proceed.
allQuestions.explanation: When you are turning right from a major road to a minor road, you must yield to oncoming traffic and proceed only when it is safe to do so. You should also be aware that there might be emerging from the minor road.

allQuestions.question: What should the driver do?
options: The driver must stop and yield to all traffic.
The driver should allow the oncoming cyclist to turn first.
The driver should allow the yellow car to proceed.
The driver may turn left first.
allQuestions.explanation: At a cross junction of equal importance the traffic approaching from the right has priority. It is important to understand that the right of way is not an absolute right. You must proceed with caution while showing regard for other road users.

allQuestions.question: What action should the driver take?
options: Stop at the stop line.
Proceed in front of the bus.
Proceed in front of the cyclist.
Signal the bus to proceed.
allQuestions.explanation: By law you must stop at a stop line (or at a STOP sign if there is no stop line), and wait for other traffic to clear before proceeding.

allQuestions.question: The driver intends to turn left at this junction - what should the driver do?
options: Allow the cyclist to continue before turning left.
Yield right of way to the van.
Allow the van and cyclist to proceed.
Turn left in front of the cyclist.
allQuestions.explanation: Do not overtake a cyclist as you approach a junction at which you are turning left. The cyclist might be continuing ahead. Cyclists are vulnerable road users and may be unstable in slow-moving traffic and at junctions. Give them more room.

allQuestions.question: The driver intends to turn right at this junction - what should the driver do?
options: Proceed after the motorcycle and bus have passed.
Proceed in front of the bus only.
Proceed after the motorcycle only.
Proceed in front of the bus and motorcyclist.
allQuestions.explanation: When you are turning right at a junction, you should yield to traffic on the major road, and to oncoming traffic at the junction.

allQuestions.question: The driver intends to turn right at this junction - what should the driver do?
options: Stop in front of the bus.
Stop at the line.
Stop in front of the motorcycle.
allQuestions.explanation: You must stop at the line where a junction is controlled by a STOP sign and stop line. Do not proceed until it is safe to do so.

allQuestions.question: When intending to turn right as shown, what should the car driver do?
options: Continue with care as the driver has right of way.
Wait and allow the oncoming vehicle to pass.
Wait and allow the truck and the oncoming vehicle to proceed first.
Wait and allow the truck to proceed first.
allQuestions.explanation: When you are turning right from a main road onto a side road, you must by law give way to oncoming traffic on the main road.

allQuestions.question: What action should a driver take on approach to the brow of this hill?
options: Reduce speed as possible hazards ahead.
Comply with the road markings.
Maintain normal speed.
allQuestions.explanation: On the approach to the brow of a hill you should be extra careful and be prepared to react to a change in the traffic situation.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do when continuing straight ahead in the middle lane?
options: Overtake the other vehicles quickly on the right-hand side.
Take any lane as convenient.
Take position in the right-hand lane even if proceeding straight ahead.
Slow down and allow the driver in front to change lanes.
allQuestions.explanation: You should always keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front especially when it is slowing down or stopping.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver be aware of when following the motorcyclist, and the white car is reversing onto the road?
options: The reversing driver will stop when they see the motorcyclist.
The motorcyclist may signal the reversing driver to stop.
The driver following the motorcycle may need a longer braking distance than normal.
The brake lights on the motorcycle may not be working.
allQuestions.explanation: You should always keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front if it is slowing down or stopping. Always read the road and be prepared to react correctly to changes in the traffic ahead.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do on the approach to this situation?
options: Reduce speed and stop if necessary.
Drive on because the oncoming traffic must wait.
Give way only if you are towing a trailer or caravan.
Increase speed in order to clear the bridge before the oncoming car.
allQuestions.explanation: When road priority is unclear you might have to yield to oncoming vehicles. Never drive a vehicle into an area that it might not be able to clear or where it could cause an obstruction or bottleneck.

allQuestions.question: When driving on this one-way street with vehicles parked on both sides, what should a driver be prepared for?
options: Pedestrians crossing between the vehicles.
Oncoming traffic as the driver overtakes the truck.
The truck may be a left-hand drive vehicle.
allQuestions.explanation: When driving on a one-way street, you should be extra careful and be prepared to react to a change in the traffic situation.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do in this situation when intending to turn left?
options: Yield to pedestrians already crossing.
Stop and beckon both pedestrians to cross.
Proceed between both pedestrians.
allQuestions.explanation: By law you must yield to pedestrians already crossing at a junction. Pedestrians are vulnerable road users and you should be extra careful driving at places where pedestrians are attempting to cross the road.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do when turning right at this junction?
options: Allow the red car to proceed.
Proceed ahead of both cars.
Allow the blue car to proceed.
Allow both cars to proceed.
allQuestions.explanation: When you are turning right from a main road into a side road, you must give way to oncoming traffic on the main road even if they are turning left into the same road.

allQuestions.question: In this situation who should wait?
options: Neither vehicle should wait.
Whichever vehicle is furthest away from the van.
The driver behind the stopped van should wait.
The oncoming vehicle must wait.
allQuestions.explanation: When you are overtaking a parked vehicle or obstruction, you should yield to oncoming vehicles so that they don't have to slow down or take evasive action.

allQuestions.question: In this situation, who should wait?
options: The driver on the main road should wait.
Both drivers should wait.
The driver in the red car should wait.
Neither driver should wait.
allQuestions.explanation: A vehicle driving on the main road has priority over vehicles emerging from side roads. However, you must understand that the right of way is not an absolute right of way and you should be considerate of other road users at all times.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver who wants to turn right do in this situation?
options: Reverse and get into the right lane.
Proceed straight ahead or turn left.
Proceed straight ahead and take a wide turn to the right.
Turn right from the left lane.
allQuestions.explanation: As you approach a junction where you want to turn right, you should read the road ahead and take up the correct position for turning in good time.

allQuestions.question: Which vehicle is in the correct position to make a right turn from the major road into the minor road?
allQuestions.explanation: The correct position from which to turn right from a major road to a minor road is just left of centre. You should take up the correct position in good time and avoid cutting the corner or swan necking - that is going beyond the turning point as car 2 is in the picture.

allQuestions.question: Which vehicle is in the correct position to make a right turn from a minor road onto a major road?
allQuestions.explanation: The correct position from which to turn right from a minor road to a major road is just left of centre of the road. You should take up the correct position in good time and complete the turn by entering the left-hand side of the major road.

allQuestions.question: What do flashing amber beacons on an oncoming vehicle alert a driver to?
options: That the oncoming vehicle is a military vehicle.
That the oncoming vehicle may be slow moving or extra wide.
That the oncoming vehicle is an emergency vehicle.
That the oncoming vehicle is fast moving.
allQuestions.explanation: Flashing amber beacons are used by recovery vehicles and vehicles carrying abnormal loads. You should be aware that these vehicles may need extra room and could conceal following traffic. When you come across such vehicles, slow down and be prepared to stop if necessary.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do if they meet a vehicle with flashing amber beacons?
options: Flash their headlights to acknowledge the beacons.
Increase speed while keeping left.
Slow down and prepare to stop.
Stop because it is an emergency vehicle.
allQuestions.explanation: Flashing amber beacons are used by recovery vehicles and vehicles carrying abnormal loads. You should be aware that these vehicles may need extra room and could conceal following traffic. When you come across such vehicles, slow down and be prepared to stop if necessary.

allQuestions.question: When preparing to stop, a driver notices the vehicle behind is towing a trailer. What should the driver do?
options: Use the handbrake to slow down and stop.
Indicate in good time and pull in gradually to allow the vehicle behind extra stopping distance.
Stop quickly keeping a close eye on the rear-view mirror.
Speed up temporarily to put distance between their vehicle and the vehicle behind.
allQuestions.explanation: When you are slowing down or stopping, you should be mindful of the type of vehicle that is following you. For example, if the vehicle following you is a large vehicle or one towing a trailer, you should think of indicating a little earlier than normal to allow the following vehicle enough time to react safely.

allQuestions.question: When approaching a bus up ahead that is signalling to move off from a bus stop, what should a driver do?
options: Slow down and allow it to move out.
Indicate and try to get past it promptly.
Stop immediately as the bus has the right of way.
allQuestions.explanation: A driver should allow signalling buses back into the stream of traffic when they are moving out from a stop. Be careful of pedestrians getting on and off buses, particularly of children near schools.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do on a narrow road when another vehicle is coming in the opposite direction?
options: Maintain position and expect the other vehicle to move over.
Reduce speed and allow reasonable clearance between their vehicle and the oncoming one before proceeding.
Position your vehicle along the middle of the road to encourage the other driver to pull in.
Maintain road position and speed. Then flash the vehicle's lights to alert the other driver to your presence.
allQuestions.explanation: You should always be prepared to react to hazards ahead. When you meet a vehicle coming against you on a narrow road, you should show consideration and slow down to a appropriate speed so that the two vehicles can pass each other safely.

allQuestions.question: When a driver is driving behind another vehicle that they do not intend to overtake, what should the driver do?
options: Keep well back and to the centre of the road.
Drive close behind it in order to let following traffic overtake both vehicles.
Keep well back to allow following traffic to overtake.
Signal to following traffic to overtake both vehicles.
allQuestions.explanation: You should always allow sufficient distance between your vehicle and the vehicle in front. This will enable you to stop safely (within the distance you can see clear). It will also give overtaking vehicles enough room to pull in safely to the left lane after they have passed you.

allQuestions.question: When a driver is driving in a line of traffic and does not intend to overtake, what should the driver do?
options: Beckon to following traffic to overtake.
Drive close to the vehicle in front.
Stay back and leave a gap for other drivers to overtake.
Indicate left as a signal to following traffic to overtake.
allQuestions.explanation: You should always allow sufficient distance between your vehicle and the vehicle in front. This will enable you to stop safely (within the distance you can see clear). It will also give overtaking vehicles enough room to pull in safely to the left lane after they have passed you.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do when being overtaken by another vehicle?
options: Move to the right.
Continue at the same pace.
Increase speed.
Slow down quickly.
allQuestions.explanation: When you are being overtaken by another vehicle, you should continue at the same pace but be alert in case the overtaking vehicle suddenly pulls back in front you.

allQuestions.question: When driving into a narrow gap between oncoming vehicles and vehicles parked on the left. What should a driver do?
options: Indicate and drive on enforcing your priority.
Always slow down, stop and wait to be beckoned forward.
Indicate right, stopping if necessary until oncoming traffic has passed by.
Signal to oncoming traffic to stop, and then move to the right and drive as normal.
allQuestions.explanation: When you meet approaching traffic at a narrow gap, you should show consideration and slow down to an appropriate speed so that you and the other vehicles can pass each other safely. If necessary, give way to the other vehicles.

allQuestions.question: When driving behind a heavy goods vehicle that is signalling to turn right, what should a driver do?
options: Stay behind until there is enough space to overtake it on the inside or until it has completed the turn.
Sound the horn and overtake the heavy goods vehicle on the right.
Overtake it slowly on the inside by driving partly on the footpath if necessary.
See if the vehicle can complete the turn without stopping, and if not, overtake it yourself.
allQuestions.explanation: Heavy goods vehicles need extra space on the road, and when they are turning the overhang of the vehicle may swing out into the path of overtaking or passing traffic. For that reason, it is a good idea to stay back and let the heavy goods vehicle complete its turn unless there is sufficient space to overtake safely.

allQuestions.question: When driving behind a bus that is signalling to turn left and there is oncoming traffic, what should a driver do?
options: Overtake it on the left-hand side.
Stay back and allow it to complete the turn.
Tap the brakes and sound the horn to signal to other vehicles to slow down.
Overtake it on the right-hand side.
allQuestions.explanation: Always allow a bus to complete a left-hand turn, because your field of view is restricted, and it could be dangerous to attempt overtaking it.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do when driving on a wide road behind a vehicle that has signalled to turn right ahead?
options: Overtake on the right-hand side and carry on.
Overtake on the left-hand side and carry on if safe to do so.
Overtake on the left, but only if turning left a short distance ahead.
Stay behind and tap the brakes to signal other drivers to slow down.
allQuestions.explanation: You may overtake on the left when the driver in front has moved out and signalled their intent to turn right and you intend to go straight ahead - provided there is enough room to do so safely and your path will not be obstructed by the swing of a large vehicle turning right.

allQuestions.question: When is it permissible to overtake another vehicle on the nearside (left-hand side)?
options: When the vehicle in front is signalling to turn right.
A driver must never overtake on the left.
When there are three lanes available in fast moving traffic.
Only when there is no cycle lane.
allQuestions.explanation: You may overtake on the left when the driver in front has moved out and signalled their intent to turn right and you intend to go straight ahead - provided there is enough room to do so safely and your path will not be obstructed by the swing of a large vehicle turning right.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do if they are behind schedule in reaching a destination at an appointed time?
options: Be patient and do not exceed the speed limit so as to arrive safely.
Exceed the speed limit if necessary to make up the time.
Use hazard warning lights to encourage other road users to let you pass.
allQuestions.explanation: You should always drive at a speed that allows you to stop safely within the distance you can see to be clear. Being late for an appointment is no excuse for exceeding speed limits or for driving at an unsafe speed. Arrive alive.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do if they are not travelling as fast as the vehicle in front?
options: The driver should keep their position and not allow following vehicles to overtake.
The driver should keep to the left and allow vehicles to overtake if they wish.
The driver should switch on hazard warning lights and keep to the left.
The driver should invite traffic to overtake them by giving a hand signal.
allQuestions.explanation: Always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to any traffic situation. You should not drive so slowly that your vehicle unnecessarily blocks other road users. Keep as near to the left as is safe to allow other vehicles to pass safely if they wish.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do if they wish to drive across a busy road and the traffic lights which normally control the junction are temporarily out of action?
options: Switch on headlights and use hand signals to show other drivers their intention to cross and then proceed.
Sound the horn and proceed slowly to cross the road.
Take good observation, wait for a clear break in the traffic and proceed to cross the road safely.
Slowly force their way across using hazard warning lights if necessary.
allQuestions.explanation: Always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to any traffic situation. In this case, do not proceed until it is clear and safe to do so. Do not assume that you have the right of way.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do if they see a school bus stopped on the nearside (left side) of the road ahead?
options: Sound the horn as a warning and continue on.
Reduce speed and overtake with caution.
Switch on hazard warning lights and stop behind the bus.
Signal and maintain current speed.
allQuestions.explanation: Always read the road and be prepared to react to any traffic situation - in this case, be aware of vulnerable road users such as school children boarding or alighting from school buses.

allQuestions.question: What should the driver do when driving behind a vehicle that is going from side to side on the road in an unsafe manner?
options: The driver should signal and go around to the left of the vehicle.
The driver should signal and go around to the right of the vehicle.
The driver should drive close behind the vehicle with a view to overtaking.
The driver should stay well back in a safe position.
allQuestions.explanation: You should always be prepared to react to hazards ahead. If the vehicle in front is moving from side to side, it may indicate that the driver is not paying full attention or that their driving is impaired by drink, drugs or tiredness. If you think the vehicle is a risk to the public safety, the matter should be reported to the Gardai or to Traffic Watch (lo-call 1890 205 805), but not while driving.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do if a heavy goods vehicle in front has moved out to make a left turn ahead?
options: Move out immediately and overtake as quickly as possible.
Move to the right but do not overtake.
Drive into the space on its left-hand side.
Stay behind it and allow it to complete the turn.
allQuestions.explanation: Always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to any traffic situation. In this case, you should be aware that the heavy goods vehicle will need extra space to complete the left-hand turn and you should remain behind the vehicle until it has completed its turn.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do if a bus in front has moved out to make a left-hand turn and there is oncoming traffic?
options: Stay back and allow the bus to complete the turn.
Maintain speed until up close behind the bus.
Overtake on the left-hand side.
Overtake on the right-hand side.
allQuestions.explanation: Always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to any traffic situation. In this case, you should be aware that the bus will need extra space to make the turn. So you should not overtake it if by doing so you would cause oncoming traffic to alter  speed or course. Remember, you should never overtake when approaching a junction.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do if they see a truck reversing into a side entrance on the left-hand side of the road ahead?
options: Try to overtake it so as not to inconvenience traffic behind.
Stop and stay back safely and wait until the way is clear.
Sound the horn to indicate to the driver of the truck to stop.
allQuestions.explanation: Always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to any traffic situation. You should be aware of the difficulties that drivers of large vehicles can have reversing into a side entrance. In this case, a large vehicle reversing could obstruct your view  of the road ahead as you approach, and you should afford the truck driver adequate space to manoeuvre.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do if they are first in line to turn right at traffic lights while the green light is showing and there is oncoming traffic approaching?
options: Remain at the stop line until a suitable gap in the oncoming traffic appears before making the turn.
Wait at the stop line for the light to turn amber and then make the turn.
Remain at the stop line until a green arrow comes on.
Go forward towards the centre of the junction and turn safely when a suitable gap appears.
allQuestions.explanation: If you wish to turn right at a set of traffic lights, drive into the junction when you see a green light, taking care not to block any oncoming traffic. Then complete the turn when it is safe to do so.

allQuestions.question: When is it permitted to force oncoming traffic onto the hard shoulder on the opposite side of the road while overtaking?
options: When the vehicle being overtaken is driving too slow.
It is not permitted to force oncoming traffic onto the hard shoulder while overtaking.
When none of the oncoming traffic is overtaking.
When the hard shoulder is wide enough.
allQuestions.explanation: Overtaking in the manner described here is dangerous. You should overtake another vehicle only when it is safe to do so, both for you and for all other traffic. Before you overtake, make sure the road ahead is clear and that you have enough room to complete the overtaking manoeuvre and return to your own side of the road without forcing any other road user to alter soeed or course.

allQuestions.question: When meeting oncoming traffic on a national road, is it permitted to move into the hard shoulder to allow following traffic to overtake?
options: No, except on '2-plus-1 roads'.
No, it is never permitted to drive on a hard shoulder except in the case of an emergency.
Yes, when a truck or bus is oncoming.
Yes, temporarily when the hard shoulder is clear and it is safe to drive there.
allQuestions.explanation: On national roads, the hard shoulder is normally for the use of pedestrians and cyclists only. If you want to allow a vehicle behind to overtake, you may pull into the hard shoulder briefly as long as no pedestrians or cyclists are using it and there are no junctions or entrances nearby. In the case of motorways, however, you must not drive on the hard shoulder, except in an emergency.

allQuestions.question: When driving on a national road is it permitted to drive on the hard shoulder in order to allow faster-moving traffic to overtake?
options: Yes, temporarily when the hard shoulder is clear and it is safe to drive there.
Only when driving on a dual carriageway.
No, except when driving on a '2-plus-1 road'.
Only when a truck or bus wants to overtake.
allQuestions.explanation: On national roads, the hard shoulder is normally for the use of pedestrians and cyclists only. If you want to allow a vehicle behind to overtake, you may pull into the hard shoulder briefly as long as no pedestrians or cyclists are using it and there are no junctions or entrances nearby. In the case of motorways, however, you must not drive on the hard shoulder, except in an emergency.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do in a queue of traffic controlled by traffic lights?
options: Overtake on the left and move to the head of the queue if there is space available.
Overtake on the right and move to the head of the queue if there is space available.
A driver should maintain their position in the queue.
Put on a right signal to prevent following vehicles from overtaking.
allQuestions.explanation: Always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to any traffic situation. From time to time you may have to queue in traffic. In this situation, you should try to remain patient and considerate of other road users. Jumping the queue is  inconsiderate, it could be dangerous, and it could even provoke a road rage incident or cause a collision.

allQuestions.question: What should the driver do when driving a vehicle they are not familiar with?
options: Drive with hazard lights on until fully familiar with the vehicle.
Initially drive with extra care and at a lower speed until fully familiar with the vehicle.
Drive at a normal speed as all vehicle's features are the same.
allQuestions.explanation: You should know where to find and how to operate all the controls on your vehicle, including all of its safety features and warning lamps. When you are driving, you need to be able to concentrate on what's happening around you and operating the vehicle controls should be second nature to you. When you sit into the driver's seat of a vehicle you are not familiar with, you should do a thorough cockpit drill before

allQuestions.question: When stopped at traffic lights and the green light comes on, what should a driver do?
options: Accelerate at a greater rate than other drivers so as to facilitate overtaking.
Check that other road users have cleared the junction and move off with care.
Move off slowly and then check the mirrors.
Move off quickly and then check the mirrors.
allQuestions.explanation: When stopped at traffic lights and the green light comes on, you should check to ensure the way is clear and proceed only if it is safe to do so.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do when they get a puncture while driving?
options: Continue on your journey and arrange for repair when convenient.
Maintain speed until a place to change the wheel is identified.
If on a motorway, stop and change the wheel immediately.
Stop at a safe place and change the wheel.
allQuestions.explanation: If you get a puncture while driving, find a suitable and safe place to stop and change the wheel. If you cant find a suitable place immediately, drive slowly (with your hazard warning lights turned on) to avoid further damage to the tyre or rim until a safe place is found.

allQuestions.question: After overtaking another vehicle, what should a driver do?
options: Continue to signal right for a distance.
Move immediately into the left after passing the vehicle.
Move back in front of the vehicle and reduce speed.
Gradually move back into the left when the vehicle has been passed.
allQuestions.explanation: After overtaking, check your mirrors, signal and return to your normal lane position as soon as it is safe. Take a smooth easy line, gradually moving back in and allowing the other vehicle plenty of space and don't cut in sharply.

allQuestions.question: What would happen if a driver cuts in too soon when overtaking another vehicle?
options: The driver would not need to indicate when moving in.
It will force oncoming vehicles to suddenly slow causing danger.
It would force the other vehicle to suddenly slow or change direction causing danger.
The safety gap between the vehicles increases.
allQuestions.explanation: When overtaking make sure the road ahead is clear so you have enough distance to overtake and get back to your own side of the road without forcing any other road user to adjust speed or direction. When you are well past the vehicle, check the mirrors, signal and gradually return to the original lane, making sure not to cut across the vehicle you have passed.

allQuestions.question: What clearance should drivers normally allow for when passing parked vehicles?
options: The width of an average person.
A car width.
The width of a side mirror.
A door width.
allQuestions.explanation: When you are passing parked vehicles, you should leave at least a door's width of clearance in case somebody opens their car door unexpectedly, this will also increase visibility of pedestrians in the area.

allQuestions.question: In dry weather how might a driver judge what is a safe following distance to vehicle in front?
options: Drive at the same speed as the vehicle in front.
By using a fixed point and applying the two second rule.
Allow a least two vehicle lengths for each kilometre per hour.
By allowing at least two vehicle lengths between the vehicles.
allQuestions.explanation: A driver can judge a safe distance from the vehicle in front by using the two second rule. This is measured by picking a fixed point. As the vehicle in front passes it, begin saying "only a fool breaks the two second rule". If you pass the fixed point before you have finished the phrase, then your vehicle is too close, safely slow and increase your distance from the vehicle in front.

allQuestions.question: What phrase is recommended for drivers to help them determine a safe distance from the vehicle in front on a dry road?
options: "Only a fool breaks the two second rule."
"Only a fool breaks the one second rule."
"Only a fool breaks the three second rule."
"Only a fool breaks the four second rule."
allQuestions.explanation: A driver can judge a safe distance from the vehicle in front by using the two second rule. This is measured by picking a fixed point. As the vehicle in front passes it, begin saying "only a fool breaks the two second rule". If you pass the fixed point before you have finished the phrase, then your vehicle is too close. Safely slow and increase your distance from the vehicle in front.

allQuestions.question: When wishing to turn right at the end of a one-way street, where should a driver position their vehicle?
options: Drive in either lane as there is no oncoming traffic.
Drive as close as possible to the left-hand side of the road.
Drive as close as is possible to the right-hand side of the road.
Drive occupying both lanes when approaching the end of the street.
allQuestions.explanation: When a driver wants to turn right on a one way street, they should check their mirrors, signal right and manoeuvre into the right-hand side when it is safe to do so. Then complete the turn into the appropriate lane of the street they are entering.

allQuestions.question: When a driver wants to turn left into a property and there is a bus lane on the left, what should the driver do?
options: Give way to cyclists, taxis and buses which may be using the bus lane.
A driver should give way to buses only.
A driver should never turn left across a bus lane.
Give way to cyclists and taxis which may be using the bus lane.
allQuestions.explanation: If a driver needs to cross a bus lane on their left in order to enter a property, they should take extra care that there are no buses, taxis or cyclists in the bus lane. They should check mirrors, signal and turn into the property when it is safe to do so.

allQuestions.question: What traffic may use a contra-flow bus lane?
options: Buses, taxis and motorcycles.
Buses and motorised wheelchairs only.
Buses, taxis and cyclists.
Buses on a scheduled service.
allQuestions.explanation: A contra-flow bus lane is one that runs in the opposite direction to traffic beside it. Only buses on a scheduled service may use a contra-flow bus lane.

allQuestions.question: What traffic may use a with-flow bus lane during the times specified on information signs at the start of the lane?
options: All traffic.
Vehicles with more than one passenger.
Buses only.
Buses, taxis and cyclists.
allQuestions.explanation: A bus lane is a special lane for the use of buses. A with-flow bus lane is one that runs in the same direction as the traffic beside it. Taxis and cyclists may also use with-flow bus lanes. Other traffic may use them outside the hours posted on the accompanying plate.

allQuestions.question: When driving along a dual carriageway in normal driving conditions, which lane should a driver be in?
options: In either lane.
In the right-hand lane.
In the right-hand lane except when driving a works vehicle or HGV.
In the left-hand lane unless the driver wishes to overtake or turn right.
allQuestions.explanation: You must normally drive in the left-hand lane of a dual carriageway, except when overtaking or turning right a short distance ahead.

allQuestions.question: What does a 2-plus-1 road have?
options: Two motorway lanes and one non-motorway lane in two directions.
Two motorway lanes in one direction and one non-motorway lane in the opposite direction.
Two non-motorway lanes in one direction and one non-motorway lane in the opposite direction.
Two non-motorway lanes and one motorway lane in two directions.
allQuestions.explanation: A 2-plus-1 road consists of two lanes in one direction of travel and one lane in the other direction. The two-lane section allows for safe overtaking and alternates with a one-lane section roughly every 2 kilometres.

allQuestions.question: What does a 2-plus-1 road have?
options: Barriers between the hard shoulder and the verge.
Two lanes for cars and one lane for trucks and buses.
Two lanes of traffic in one direction and one in the opposite direction.
Barriers between lanes of traffic going in the same direction.
allQuestions.explanation: A 2-plus-1 road consists of two lanes in one direction of travel and one lane in the other direction. The two-lane section allows for safe overtaking and alternates with a one-lane section roughly every 2 kilometres.

allQuestions.question: Where may a driver overtake on a 2-plus-1 road?
options: In the one-lane stretch if there is no oncoming traffic.
In the one-lane stretch.
In either the one-lane stretch or the two-lane stretch.
In the two-lane stretch.
allQuestions.explanation: A 2-plus-1 road consists of two lanes in one direction of travel and one lane in the other direction. When you need to overtake, you should wait until you reach the 2- lane section which occurs approximately every 2 kilometres.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do when travelling on a motorway or dual carriageway?
options: Relax because there will be no oncoming traffic.
Be alert for other drivers who may suddenly change lanes or reduce speed.
Match the speed to that of the vehicle in the adjoining lane.
Match the speed to that of the vehicle in front.
allQuestions.explanation: Motorways and dual carriageways are designed to help traffic travel faster and more safely between destinations. Traffic conditions can change very quickly because of the speed and increased volumes of traffic and lanes, and you need to be particularly alert to other drivers changing lanes or reducing speed.

allQuestions.question: In normal driving conditions on a motorway, which lane should the driver occupy?
options: Drive in the offside (right-hand) lane unless intending to take a left exit.
Drive in the offside (right-hand) lane as the nearside (left-hand) lane is for HGVs and buses only.
Constantly manoeuvre between whichever lane has the least volume of traffic.
Drive in the nearside (left-hand) lane unless intending to overtake.
allQuestions.explanation: The normal keep left rules apply when you are driving on a motorway - a driver should stay in the nearside (left-hand) lane unless they are overtaking.

allQuestions.question: What may the hard shoulder of a motorway be used for?
options: Joining the motorway.
Exiting the motorway.
Stopping in an emergency.
Stopping to use a mobile phone.
allQuestions.explanation: There are extra dangers when driving on a motorway because of the increased volume of traffic and higher speed. For safety reasons a driver should not drive or stop on the hard shoulder of a motorway except in an emergency or breakdown.

allQuestions.question: After exiting the motorway and coming towards a junction at the end of the deceleration lane (slip road) what should a driver do?
options: Maintain motorway speeds to the end of the slip road.
Be alert for oncoming and crossing traffic at the end of the slip road.
The driver must always stop at the end of a slip road.
The driver should continue at the junction as traffic on the slip road has right of way.
allQuestions.explanation: The driver should check for signs showing a lower speed; use the speedometer to make sure that they are obeying the reduced speed limit; remember that the slip roads and link roads between motorways may include sharp bends and that they may encounter junctions and other traffic. Remember that motorway rules no longer apply.

allQuestions.question: A driver wishes to go straight ahead at a cross junction of equal importance. If they encounter other traffic, what is the general rule that applies?
options: Traffic approaching from the driver's right has right of way.
Carry on as normal as they always have the right of way.
Give way to traffic approaching firstly from the left and then the right.
Give way to traffic approaching from the left only.
allQuestions.explanation: If a driver is at a junction where the roads are of equal importance, traffic on the driver's right has the right of way. The driver must let that traffic pass before moving on. It is important to understand that the right of way is not an absolute right. Drivers must proceed with caution whilst showing regard for other users of the road.

allQuestions.question: In general, when turning right on a two-way road, where should a driver position the vehicle?
options: At either side of the middle of the road.
At the far left-hand side of the road.
At the far right-hand side of the road.
Just left of the middle of the road.
allQuestions.explanation: In general, the correct position to be in before turning right is just left of the centre of the road. Where the road is wide enough, this position allows traffic coming from behind and going straight ahead to pass safely on the left. The driver should be alert for road markings which direct them to follow a certain course.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do before turning right from a major road into a minor road?
options: Stop and signal traffic to exit left from the minor road.
Yield right of way to oncoming traffic and to pedestrians crossing at the junction.
Commence turn in front of oncoming traffic as they must yield to traffic turning right.
Stop and signal traffic to exit right from the minor road.
allQuestions.explanation: The driver must yield to oncoming traffic and to pedestrians who are already crossing when turning right from a major road to a minor road.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do when an emergency service vehicle approaches with flashing blue lights?
options: Brake suddenly to allow the emergency service vehicle to pass.
Do nothing and ignore the emergency service vehicle.
React quickly, safely and carefully to allow the emergency service vehicle to pass.
Increase speed to prevent obstructing the emergency service vehicle.
allQuestions.explanation: A driver needs to know what to do when they see an emergency vehicle. A driver must react quickly, safely and carefully to allow emergency service vehicles to pass. It is important to be alert and attentive at all times.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver never do when an emergency service vehicle approaches with flashing blue lights?
options: React quickly, safely and carefully to allow the emergency service vehicle to pass.
Brake suddenly or block the road.
Pull over in a place which has enough space for the emergency service vehicle to pass safely.
Clear the way as soon as possible.
allQuestions.explanation: A driver needs to know what to do when they see an emergency vehicle. A driver must react quickly, safely and carefully to allow emergency service vehicles to pass. It is important to be alert and attentive at all times.

allQuestions.question: Can a driver break a red light or break the speed limit to allow an emergency service vehicle to pass?
options: No, a driver should never break a red light or speed up to allow an emergency service vehicle to pass.
Yes, a driver may break the speed limit to allow an emergency service vehicle to pass.
Yes, a driver may legally break a red light to allow an emergency service vehicle to pass.
No, except where the junction or road is clear, then a driver can break a red light or speed up to allow an emergency service vehicle to pass.
allQuestions.explanation: A driver needs to know what to do when they see an emergency vehicle. A driver must react quickly, safely and carefully to allow emergency service vehicles to pass. It is important to be alert and attentive at all times.

allQuestions.question: What is the likely effect of motorists 'rubbernecking' at the scene of a traffic incident?
options: It allows traffic to change course without attention.
It allows traffic to change speed without attention.
It can cause additional incidents as drivers become distracted.
It can increase traffic flow near an incident.
allQuestions.explanation: When approaching or being near to the scene of an incident, motorists are often seen 'rubbernecking'. This means turning your head and stretching your neck to get a better view of what's happening. It can be the cause of traffic jams as drivers slow down to 'rubberneck'. It can also cause road incidents as drivers become distracted and change their soeed and/or direction while other drivers are also distracted.

allQuestions.question: How should a driver react to emergency services vehicles with flashing blue lights and/or sirens on?
options: Brake suddenly and stop to avoid causing obstruction.
Mount kerb on offside of the road to make room.
Only move aside if it is an ambulance.
Check their mirrors before looking for space to move aside.
allQuestions.explanation: If you see any emergency vehicle approaching with lights and/or sirens activated, check your rear view mirrors to gauge the speed of the emergency vehicle/s and also look out for pedestrians, cyclists, motorcyclists and other road users. Indicate your intention to pull over. Pull over only in a space that has enough space for the emergency vehicle/s to pass safely. Move off safely with appropriate observations

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do if a front tyre bursts while driving?
options: Relax the hold on the steering wheel.
Brake firmly and quickly.
Grip the steering wheel firmly.
Apply the handbrake immediately.
allQuestions.explanation: If a front tyre bursts on a vehicle, the steering on the vehicle will become unstable. Don't panic - slow down gradually while keeping a firm hold on the steering wheel. Stop in a safe place to change the wheel, and alert other road users by switching on  your hazard warning lights.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do if their vehicle gets a puncture on a motorway?
options: Pull in where safe on the hard shoulder and call for assistance.
Drive on to the next service area and get assistance.
Stop in the hard shoulder and get a passenger to warn traffic.
Stop in the traffic lane and switch on the hazard warning lights.
allQuestions.explanation: Don't try to change a wheel on a motorway, as this could be very dangerous. Drive the car on to the hard shoulder, and when it is safe to do so, get out of the vehicle and move behind the barrier. Call for assistance from a motorway emergency phone or using a mobile phone (call the Gardai).

allQuestions.question: What precautions could a driver take against the risk of fire in their vehicle?
options: Carry a suitable fire extinguisher in the vehicle.
Keep all water levels filled to the maximum at all times.
Use low-octane unleaded petrol in the vehicle.
Avoid driving the vehicle with a full tank of fuel.
allQuestions.explanation: A strong smell of fuel is usually an indication that something is wrong, and you should stop and investigate as soon as possible. Leaking or spilling petrol can be dangerous because it is so combustible. It is good practice to carry a fire extinguisher in your vehicle, so that you can deal with any small fires.

allQuestions.question: When should a driver use hazard warning lights on a motorway?
options: When another vehicle is following too closely.
When the vehicle is towing a trailer.
When driving on the hard shoulder.
When the vehicle has broken down.
allQuestions.explanation: If your vehicle breaks down on a motorway, drive it to the hard shoulder and switch on the hazard warning lights to warn following traffic. When it is safe to do so, get out of the vehicle and move behind the barrier. Call for assistance from a motorway emergency phone or using a mobile phone (call the Gardai).

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do if their vehicle is broken down on a motorway and they are awaiting assistance?
options: Try to flag down other traffic from the rear of the vehicle for assistance.
Switch on the vehicle hazard warning lights, get out of the vehicle and stand safely to the side.
Get out of the vehicle and wait at the rear of it.
Stand out on the roadway and direct traffic to pass.
allQuestions.explanation: If your vehicle breaks down on the road, always switch on the hazard warning lights and stand clear of the vehicle while awaiting assistance - this will warn other traffic that there is a vehicle stopped on the road.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do when they see plant or machinery crossing the roadway at roadworks up ahead?
options: Leave the carriage way as the road ahead is blocked.
Maintain the same speed along the road.
Slow down and prepare to stop.
allQuestions.explanation: When you notice works vehicles ahead, slow down and be prepared to stop for the road works. If machinery is crossing you must stop if directed.

allQuestions.question: What action should a driver take when they meet a vehicle with flashing blue lights?
options: Flash the headlights and drive up onto the footpath on the left.
Switch on the vehicle hazard warning lights.
Flash the headlights and come to an immediate stop.
Move to the left, reduce speed and stop if necessary.
allQuestions.explanation: When a driver notices an emergency vehicle approaching in the distance, they should check their mirror and move to the left to allow the vehicle to pass. On some occasions it may be necessary to stop.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver do if an ambulance is stopped up ahead with its flashing blue lights on?
options: Reduce speed and prepare to stop if necessary.
Move to the centre of the road to stop other vehicles from overtaking.
Stop immediately to see what is happening.
Stop and offer assistance.
allQuestions.explanation: When you come upon an emergency vehicle stopped on the road, you should slow down and be prepared to stop. Do not stop to see what is happening as this could be dangerous and you might cause an obstruction to the flow of traffic.

allQuestions.question: How are emergency vehicles identified?
options: By flashing red or blue lights.
By flashing green lights.
By continuously lit red lights.
By flashing amber and white lights.
allQuestions.explanation: If you hear or see an emergency vehicle approaching sounding its siren or flashing lights, be extra careful and give way if it is safe to do so.

allQuestions.question: What is the penalty for a vehicle owner who allows a learner driver to drive their vehicle unaccompanied?
options: Their vehicle will be seized.
They will incur 2 penalty points on their licence.
They will be fined €2,000.
They will lose their driving licence.
allQuestions.explanation: A learner driver needs to be aware that driving unaccompanied in a vehicle, even where the owner has given their consent to drive, may result in the vehicle being seized.

allQuestions.question: A learner permit driver who receives 7 penalty points in a 36 month period (three years) will be banned from driving for how many months?
options: 3 months.
6 months.
12 months.
9 months.
allQuestions.explanation: A learner driver needs to be aware that there is a lower penalty point threshold for learner or novice drivers.

allQuestions.question: If there is no footpath, where must a pedestrian walk?
options: There is no regulation.
1 metre from the edge of the road.
Right-hand side of the road.
Left-hand side of the road.
allQuestions.explanation: Where there is no footpath provided, pedestrians should walk on the right-hand side of the road facing oncoming traffic. Drivers should be aware of the Rules of the Road for pedestrians, drive with caution and be prepared to react to any changes in the traffic situation.

allQuestions.question: On a narrow busy road, what should pedestrians do when walking?
options: Walk more than two abreast.
Walk in groups of no more than three.
Walk two abreast.
Walk in single file.
allQuestions.explanation: Pedestrians should walk in single file on busy narrow roads. Drivers should be aware of the Rules of the Road for pedestrians, drive with caution and be prepared to react to any changes in the traffic situation.

allQuestions.question: When should pedestrians wear reflective clothing at night?
options: At night, when walking outside built-up areas.
When walking two abreast.
Only when it is raining.
When in urban areas.
allQuestions.explanation: Outside built-up areas, pedestrians should wear reflective clothing at all times when walking at night. This is particularly important where there is no street lighting and no footpath for pedestrians.

allQuestions.question: What should the car driver do in this situation?
options: The driver must allow the cyclist to proceed.
The driver may turn right before the cyclist.
The driver must allow the motorcyclist to proceed.
The driver must stop and yield right of way to the other road users.
allQuestions.explanation: When you are turning right from a major road to a minor road, you must yield to oncoming traffic, and you should proceed only when it is safe to do so.

allQuestions.question: What should the car driver do in this situation?
options: The car driver is not allowed to turn right.
The car driver must allow the bus to proceed.
The car driver may proceed first.
The car driver must allow the motorcycle to proceed.
allQuestions.explanation: When you are turning right from a major road to a minor road, you must yield to oncoming traffic. You should proceed only when it is safe to do so.

allQuestions.question: What should a driver be alert to in this area?
options: Parked vehicles may have trailers attached.
There may be refuse bins between the parked vehicles.
Pedestrians may be hitch-hiking.
Pedestrians may cross between parked cars.
